summary: Paul Merson and Andros Townsend had a public disagreement after Townsend was brought on as a substitute in Tottenham's 0-0 draw with Burnley, with Merson criticizing Townsend's inclusion in the England squad. Merson later admitted he was wrong when Townsend scored a goal for England against Italy, and the two seemed to reconcile. However, Merson made another comment about Townsend's place in the squad after Tottenham's draw with Burnley.

Chelsea has made an offer for FC Tokyo's 22-year-old forward Yoshinori Muto, who will join Vitesse Arnhem on loan if the move to Chelsea is completed this summer. Muto, who has played for FC Tokyo since 2013, has scored 16 goals in 37 appearances for the club and 1 goal in 11 international matches for Japan. The offer is not related to Chelsea's £200 million sponsorship deal with Yokohama Rubber.

A large-scale study published in Pediatrics found that babies given antibiotics in their first six months of life are more likely to be overweight or obese as toddlers. The researchers suggest that antibiotics, commonly used to promote weight gain in farm animals, may also contribute to childhood obesity. The study, which compared over 12,000 healthy two-year-olds with antibiotic prescription records, found that by age two, one in five boys and one in ten girls were overweight or obese. Children who received antibiotics as young babies were particularly likely to be overweight, with boys showing a greater tendency for weight gain and slightly increased height. While the study does not prove a direct cause-and-effect relationship, it highlights the potential role of antibiotics in the global childhood obesity epidemic and emphasizes the need for cautious antibiotic use in infancy.

A Buckingham Palace guard slipped and fell on a manhole cover during the Changing of the Guard ceremony, causing him to drop his rifle and knock his bearskin on the side of the box. The incident, captured on camera by tourist David Meadwell, left the embarrassed soldier red-faced as he scrambled to his feet and his colleagues continued marching as if nothing had happened. The guard is believed to have slipped due to the metal protectors on his boots. The Changing of the Guard, a popular daily event at Buckingham Palace, is attended by thousands of tourists who watch the fully operational soldiers perform their duties.

The passage discusses the remaking of the 1977 TV miniseries "Roots" for new audiences in 2016. The original miniseries, based on Alex Haley's novel, had over 100 million viewers. A&E networks, Lifetime, and History (formerly the History Channel) will simulcast the remake, which will be more "original" and "contemporary," drawing from the novel and consulting scholars for authenticity. LeVar Burton, who played Kunta Kinte in the original, will co-executive produce the new version. The remake aims to reach a new generation, including those who witnessed significant historical events like Barack Obama's presidency and the film "12 Years a Slave" winning Best Picture.

A former royal footman, Christopher Lawler, claims that palace aides at Clarence House attempted to force him into an orgy in 1978 when he was 27 years old. Lawler was pinned to a chair and groped by a male staff member on his first day, leaving him in tears and causing him to quit the same day. He only recently reported the incident to palace officials after inquiries began into alleged cover-ups of child sex abuse. Police are now investigating the claims, but Lawler's initial complaint was ignored for months before being passed to Scotland Yard. A retired royal aide, now in his 80s, was reportedly interviewed but denied involvement. The Palace has stated they will cooperate with any police probe.

An Oregon couple, Jesse and Melissa Meek, announced their pregnancy in a rap video set to the theme song from the 1990s TV show "The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air." The video, which has garnered over 1.7 million views on YouTube, features the couple rapping about their new family addition. The Meeks filmed the video to inform loved ones living far away about the baby. They plan to make another video if they learn the gender of the child.

A dress worn by Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O'Hara in the 1939 film Gone With the Wind sold for $137,000 at auction in Beverly Hills, California. The gray jacket and skirt ensemble, originally slate blue-gray but faded over time, was one of over 150 items from the private collection of James Tumblin, who began collecting onscreen memorabilia from the film in the 1960s. Other notable items from the auction included a straw hat worn by Leigh ($52,500), Clark Gable's suit trousers and jacket ($55,000), and a black bonnet worn by Leigh and Olivia De Havilland ($30,000).

A two-year-old boy fell into a cheetah exhibit at the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo after slipping between 10 to 12 feet while his parents were holding him and another child. He suffered minor injuries and was listed in stable condition at MetroHealth Medical Center. The zoo plans to press child endangerment charges against the family.

A speed camera previously used to enforce a 30mph speed limit on Wellington Road in Handsworth, Birmingham, has been re-pointed to face a house on the road, despite being non-functional for over two years due to the decommissioning of fixed location safety cameras across the West Midlands in 2013. The camera's re-pointing is under investigation, with Birmingham City Council confirming no plans to include it in a new pilot program using digital technology.

Usain Bolt, a six-time Olympic gold medallist, will compete in the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas on May 2 and 3 as part of the Jamaican team. Bolt expressed his excitement about representing Jamaica and his readiness to run, noting the meet's fun atmosphere from the previous year. The Jamaican Athletics Administrative Association (JAAA) is pleased to have Bolt as part of their team, expecting "sprint magic" during the competition. The full Jamaican team list will be announced soon.

Barcelona's football stars Neymar and Dani Alves supported the club's basketball team by attending an El Clasico match against Real Madrid. Neymar's sister Rafaella also joined them. Despite Real Madrid's lead in the Euro League, Barcelona remains four points clear at the top of La Liga. Neymar recently helped Brazil secure a 1-0 win over Chile, while his team prepares to face Celta Vigo in La Liga.

In recent months, Italy has been facing a surge in migrant arrivals from Africa and the Middle East, with 8,480 migrants rescued between Friday and Monday alone. On Tuesday, Save the Children expressed concern over 400 missing migrants after a ship carrying 550 people capsized in the Mediterranean Sea off Libya, though the Italian coast guard could not confirm this incident. The influx of migrants, primarily from West Africa, Somalia, and Syria, often uses Libya as a transit country. The International Organization for Migration reports that at least 480 migrants have died crossing the Mediterranean this year due to factors like bad weather and overcrowded vessels.

Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger is pleased that Alexis Sanchez chose Arsenal over Liverpool, despite Liverpool's interest during negotiations for Luis Suarez. Sanchez, who has scored 19 goals this season, impressed Wenger with his quick adaptation to the new environment and his qualities such as efficiency, work-rate, and fighting spirit. Wenger also downplayed speculation about a potential transfer for Liverpool's Raheem Sterling, praising Brendan Rodgers' development of the team despite recent setbacks.

Four-time Olympic champion Bradley Wiggins will attempt to break the cycling hour record at London's Olympic Velodrome on June 7. Wiggins, who finished his Team Sky career in the Paris-Roubaix race, aims to ride the furthest distance in 60 minutes, potentially setting a new record that could last for some time. The event, expected to draw a capacity crowd of 6,000, will be broadcast live on Sky Sports. Wiggins, who has four gold, one silver, and two bronze Olympic medals, hopes to add to his achievements and motivate others to challenge themselves by attempting the record.

Serena Williams, the world's top-ranked tennis player, overcame a challenging clay court season to defeat Italian Sara Errani 4-6, 7-6(3), 6-3 in the Fed Cup play-off, marking her 8th victory over Errani. However, Williams expressed surprise at her lack of readiness for the clay court season, stating she needs to be more prepared. The US team, led by Williams, lost the doubles match 6-0, 6-3 to Errani and Flavia Pennetta, resulting in their relegation to World Group II. This defeat, coupled with Williams' poor performance on clay courts, has raised concerns about the US team's competitiveness in the upcoming year.

River Plate is interested in signing Manchester United striker Radamel Falcao, despite the deal being complicated. The 29-year-old Colombian forward has struggled on loan at Manchester United, scoring only four Premier League goals. Falcao, who previously spent eight years with River Plate, is open to returning to the Argentine club. Falcao has been in good form for his national team, scoring three goals in two games to equal Colombia's all-time goalscoring record.

X Factor finalist and pop star Ella Henderson has become the official face of dry shampoo brand Batiste for their 2015 'Ready For It' campaign, marking her first brand collaboration. The campaign features Henderson with various hairstyles against a blurred city background, showcasing her glossy, wavy, and half-ponytail hair. The partnership between the platinum award-winning artist and the UK's number 1 dry shampoo brand was formed by the MILES agency, with Henderson expressing her excitement about working with the brand, as she uses it regularly.

Family and friends of Aaron Siler, a 26-year-old man fatally shot by police officer Pablo Torres on March 14 in Kenosha, Wisconsin, are outraged after a billboard featuring Torres was erected in the city. The billboard, paid for by the Kenosha Professional Police Association, includes a photo of Torres and his dog with the message "Thank you for your support, Kenosha." Siler's family and friends find the billboard disrespectful, with one friend stating it feels like a "thank you for killing Aaron." Torres is currently on leave pending the outcome of the investigation into Siler's death, which is being conducted by the state Division of Criminal Investigation. The shooting occurred after a vehicle and foot pursuit, with Siler wanted on an active felony probation and parole warrant. The Kenosha Professional Police Association claims no offense was intended, stating the billboard was a gesture of community support.

Eight Iranian border guards were killed in clashes with militants near the border with Pakistan on Monday. The militants, who crossed into Iran from Pakistan, were responsible for the attack, which Iranian officials have asked Pakistani authorities to catch the surviving assailants. Jaish al Adal, an anti-Iranian militant group, claimed responsibility for the attack. The group has targeted Shiites and aims to thwart Iranian influence in Pakistan. Pakistani authorities condemned the attack, calling it an "act of terrorism" and stated that they are actively investigating the incident.

Japanese Defense Minister Gen Nakatani confirmed that the country's Air Self Defense Force has never encountered an extraterrestrial unidentified flying object (UFO) and that they only take action against objects that could potentially violate Japanese airspace. This response came in answer to a question from former wrestler-turned-lawmaker Antonio Inoki, who had inquired about the detection and research of UFOs. Inoki, known for his political career and mixed martial arts background, has also claimed to have seen a UFO himself, though he remains uncertain about the existence of aliens.

A 35-year-old passenger, Jin Pai, was hospitalized after breaking a toilet while standing on its rim at Hefei Xinqiao International Airport in eastern China. He had been squatting on the toilet due to concerns about cleanliness, but the porcelain structure collapsed, causing deep cuts on his leg and buttocks. Despite his friends' attempts to help, he was too injured to seek immediate assistance. He initially claimed he was sitting on the toilet but later admitted to police that he was standing, possibly to avoid compensation. Authorities confirmed the incident as an accident and advised passengers to use toilets for sitting only.

Kevin Rebbie, 56, of Limerick Township, Pennsylvania, was arrested for allegedly sexually abusing a 15-year-old girl and others over a four-year period. He was found with a hidden camera in a bathroom that captured 41 videos, including footage of the girl and others showering. Rebbie faces charges including aggravated indecent assault, unlawful contact with a minor, sexual abuse of children, and invasion of privacy. The investigation began when the girl discovered the hidden camera in her home in March. Rebbie admitted to filming several victims, including other juveniles, and uploaded the videos to his computer. His preliminary hearing is scheduled for May 1, and he is being held on a $500,000 bail.

Japanese photographer Yûki Aoyama's new series of photos features fathers leaping into the air while their daughters look directly at the camera, smiling. The images, part of a book titled "Daughter and Salaryman," showcase the fathers in energetic poses, often in sharp suits, symbolizing their fun side. The series, which includes various Japanese landmarks in the background, has garnered online interest despite limited information about its origin.

Kevin Pietersen, previously dismissed as England's managing director, is set to return to the international cricket scene as Surrey begins their County Championship season on April 19. Pietersen, who last played for England during the disastrous 2013 Ashes tour, has rejoined Surrey in hopes of regaining his place in the Test team. The team photo shoot at the KIA Oval, held before the start of the season, saw Pietersen in deep thought and a jovial mood, joking with photographers and teammates.

Romanian club Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt fired Brazilian coach Ze Maria for the second time in a week due to poor performance, only to reinstate him the next day after owner Angelo Massone decided to give the coaching staff another chance. Ze Maria, a former Brazil defender with 25 international caps, was replaced by Serbian Vanya Radinovic. Ceahlaul currently stands 16th in the standings, six points away from safety.

Nabil Dirar, Radamel Falcao's former Monaco teammate, believes the Colombian striker must regret his loan move to Manchester United, despite not being happy in France. Falcao joined United on a season-long loan last summer but has struggled to reach his previous form due to a serious knee injury. United would need to pay £46 million for a permanent transfer, but with only four goals scored this season, it is unlikely they will take up the option. Dirar thinks Falcao would have been better off staying at Monaco, where he could have played in the Champions League, but may have needed more atmosphere.

New Zealand police are seeking public assistance to identify a tall man who robbed a Christchurch dairy on Saturday, wearing a distinctive cartoon mask and demanding cash from the owner's daughter. The suspect, seen on security footage in a fluoro orange sweatshirt and oversized mask, fled with the dairy's till and approximately $1,500 in cash. Police have not found any weapons but are urging anyone with information to contact Crimestoppers or message police online.

Texas math teacher Kaitlyn Granado, 24, was arrested twice for having inappropriate sexual relationships with underage students. First arrested in March for a relationship with a 15-year-old student, she was later arrested again in March for allegedly having sex with another 15-year-old student on two consecutive nights in January. Granado admitted to kissing and allowing the second student to touch her breasts in a police interview. She was released after posting $50,000 bail and is currently on administrative leave from her teaching position at MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas.

A video of a large crocodile swimming through a Puerto Vallarta marina in Mexico with a dead pet dog in its jaws has been viewed over half a million times online. The incident occurred when a New Zealander, Tim Weston, and his wife were on holiday. The dog belonged to the local bike shop owner. The crocodile calmly held onto the dog for hours as crowds gathered to watch. The crocodile is a common sight in Puerto Vallarta due to the mangroves and urbanization bringing the creatures closer to humans.

Hull City manager Steve Bruce remains confident the team can avoid relegation from the Premier League despite a 2-0 defeat to Southampton, which left them needing nine or eight wins to stay up. Bruce acknowledges the challenge, citing long-term injuries to key players as a factor in their struggles. Hull has six games left to save their season, including tough matches against Liverpool, Arsenal, Tottenham, and Manchester United. The team is currently two points above the relegation zone, and Bruce believes positive thinking and securing results will help them stay in the league.

A teacher, Ian Guffick, was banned from teaching for at least two years after he allowed students to change their SATs exam answers, invalidating the school's results. Despite claiming he only asked for more legible answers, the National College for Teaching and Leadership found his actions breached exam rules. The Department for Education annulled all SATs results for the school, and Guffick was dismissed from his position. He admitted to the allegations and expressed regret, but the panel deemed his misconduct as unacceptable professional conduct, not amounting to fraud.

Anders Lindegaard, the Manchester United goalkeeper, recently celebrated his marriage to Swedish model Misse Beqiri, who he has been dating since 2012. The couple tied the knot in a beach wedding in Mauritius last year and have a son together. Despite struggling for playing time at Old Trafford, Lindegaard shared a photo on Instagram with Beqiri, enjoying a day off together. The Danish international has made only 19 league appearances in five seasons at Manchester United, often relegated to cup matches, and is now the third-choice goalkeeper behind David de Gea and Victor Valdes.

The 13 glowing blue letters that illuminated Yankee Stadium from 1976 until the stadium's final game in 2008 failed to sell at a Sotheby's auction, despite estimates of $300,000 to $600,000. Only a Sotheby's employee bid $260,000. The letters, owned by Yankee Hall of Famer Reggie Jackson, were purchased "on a lark" and Jackson joked he might have overestimated their value.

Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers has addressed Raheem Sterling and Jordon Ibe over their recent behavior, which included Sterling inhaling nitrous oxide and both being seen with shisha pipes. Despite not disciplining the players, Rodgers emphasized the importance of professional responsibilities and learning from the incident. He highlighted that while some actions may seem normal, their framing can have significant consequences. Rodgers also expressed his focus on steering Liverpool to their first FA Cup final of his tenure, recalling their near-miss in the title race and the last four of the Capital One Cup. He praised the team's resilience and readiness to progress, noting that losses and setbacks are part of the journey to success.

Mesut Ozil, Arsenal's playmaker, enjoyed his return to London after the international break, sharing a photo of him relaxing with his dog. Ozil, who joined Arsenal for £42.5 million in 2013, impressed in Germany's 2-0 Euro 2016 qualifier win against Georgia. He is now focused on Arsenal's upcoming Premier League match against Liverpool. Despite missing the previous game due to illness, Ozil has been in good form since returning from injury, contributing four assists and scoring three goals since January. He has adjusted well to English football, finding the demanding schedule beneficial for his playing style.

Barcelona president Josep Maria Bartomeu has denied rumors of Luis Enrique's replacement, expressing satisfaction with the manager's performance. Enrique, who took over last summer, is six games away from winning the La Liga title. The 44-year-old has a contract until 2016, and the club remains confident in his ability to secure three trophies this season.

Liverpool midfielder Jordan Henderson has agreed to a new long-term contract with the club, worth around £100,000 per week and running until 2020. This comes after his advisors began talks with the club earlier in the season. Henderson, 24, is the third major player to sign a contract extension under manager Brendan Rodgers, following Daniel Sturridge and Philippe Coutinho. He has been one of the most improved players for Liverpool, contributing 13 assists and seven goals this season, and is considered for the role of club captain when Steven Gerrard departs.

Filipe Luis, who signed a three-year contract with Chelsea last July, has expressed his desire to stay with the club until the end of his contract despite Atletico Madrid showing interest in re-signing him. Despite struggling to establish himself at left back, Luis remains committed to Chelsea, with manager Jose Mourinho urging the team to focus and perform at their best in the remaining difficult matches of the Premier League season.

Nathan Hughes had his three-match ban overturned after accidentally knocking out George North during a match on March 27. Initially suspended for recklessness, the disciplinary panel rescinded the ban following an appeal by Wasps, citing a lack of intent and overwhelming public support. North suffered a concussion, leading to Hughes being advised to take a month off from playing. The incident, captured in slow-motion, sparked controversy but ultimately resulted in Hughes being cleared.

The passage describes a series of intense red sunsets in Washington, Seattle, and parts of Oregon and British Columbia, caused by wildfires in southeastern Siberia. The fires, which began on April 14 and were exacerbated by strong winds, have destroyed numerous villages and released smoke that was carried by atmospheric winds across the Pacific Ocean. The smoke particles filter out shorter wavelength colors from sunlight, allowing red and orange hues to penetrate and create the vivid sunsets. As the smoke dissipates, air quality will improve, and the sunsets will lose their reddish appearance.

Becky Schoenig, a mom from St. Louis, Missouri, had her brand new 2015 Ford Fusion stolen from her driveway. After a month, police found the car after a tip from a man who recognized it as hers and returned it with red rims, detailing, and orange accents on the steering wheel. Instead of being upset, Schoenig took to Facebook to thank the thieves, jokingly calling the car "pimped out." She is now having the vehicle professionally cleaned to remove the smell of cigarettes and marijuana and is creating a smoothie at her restaurant, The Hot Pot, to honor Mick Sexton, the man who located her car and notified the police.

Manchester City players will lose £500,000 in bonuses if they fail to qualify for the Champions League this season. The team's star players, including Sergio Aguero, David Silva, Joe Hart, and Yaya Toure, have incentivized contracts to ensure financial fairplay compliance. City currently sits in fourth place, just four points ahead of Liverpool, who could overtake them after a potential win against Newcastle United. The top three Premier League finishers automatically qualify for the Champions League, while the fourth-place team must win a qualifying round. The squad's £12 million bonus pool depends on reaching the European target. Manager Manuel Pellegrini has criticized the team's recent performance, admitting they have "thrown it into the garbage" and must improve.

The passage describes a 'mini derby' match between Manchester United's Under 18s and Altrincham, where United won 1-0. The match featured 13 out of 22 players being English, with 10 being from Manchester. Callum Gribbin scored the winning goal with a free-kick. The match was played at Altrincham's 6,000-capacity stadium, providing a more grand stage than United's usual training ground. The result leaves United with two points behind leaders Middlesbrough in the Barclays Under 18s Premier League end-of-season play-off series.

England goalkeeper Joe Hart praised fellow goalkeeper Gianluigi Buffon, calling him a "legend of the game" after Buffon earned his 147th cap against England. Hart, who reached his 50th cap milestone, expressed admiration for Buffon's career and expressed his desire to continue playing well for his club and country.

Chipotle Mexican Grill is entering the $70 billion food delivery market by partnering with the Postmates app to offer delivery in 67 cities. Customers can expect a 9% service charge, with Postmates delivery fees starting at $5 depending on distance and demand. This move comes after Chipotle previously declined similar collaboration offers. The delivery service will join other fast-food chains like Starbucks, Taco Bell, McDonald's, and Burger King that are also expanding into the delivery market.

The parents of Martin Richard, one of the youngest victims of the 2013 Boston Marathon bombings, are urging the Justice Department to drop the death penalty for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, the man convicted in the case. Martin and two others were killed, and over 200 people were wounded when two bombs exploded at the race's finish line. The Richards, who also lost their 7-year-old daughter Jane to injuries, argue that pursuing the death penalty could prolong their pain and relive the traumatic event. They propose that Tsarnaev should spend the rest of his life in prison without the possibility of release and waive his right to appeal.

A custom-built Boeing 747-8, valued at £400 million, has been transformed into an ultra-luxurious private jet for a billionaire. The aircraft, originally designed to carry up to 600 passengers, now features bedrooms, lounges, a restaurant, a conference room, and an "aeroloft" with eight beds, providing a hotel-like experience for its single owner and occasional guests.

SpaceX successfully launched a Falcon 9 rocket carrying an uncrewed Dragon cargo spacecraft to the International Space Station from Cape Canaveral, Florida. However, the attempt to land the rocket stage on a floating barge was unsuccessful, as the rocket tipped over upon landing. SpaceX founder Elon Musk aims to reduce space access costs by reusing rockets like airplanes. The Dragon will deliver over 4,300 pounds of supplies to the space station and return with scientific experiments and waste. This is SpaceX's second attempt for this mission, with the first scrubbed due to weather.

Priscilla Presley, the ex-wife of Elvis Presley, will serve as a witness at the first wedding at the newly opened Elvis Presley's Graceland Wedding Chapel in Las Vegas. The chapel, located inside the Westgate Hotel, will host the wedding of one Elvis-obsessed couple announced next Monday. The winning couple will receive a free wedding, reception, hotel suite, airfares, and concert tickets. Priscilla emphasized that the chapel is a serious, first-class event and not a joke. Couples interested in participating must submit a video, photos, and an explanation of why they deserve the prize.

Liverpool vice-captain Jordan Henderson believes his team could catch Manchester City in the Premier League, despite a challenging season. Henderson and goalkeeper Simon Mignolet both reached 47 appearances this season, setting a record for the most games in the top five European leagues. After a series of poor results, including losses to Manchester United and Arsenal, Liverpool secured a 2-0 win over Newcastle United, with Raheem Sterling and Joe Allen scoring. Henderson emphasized the importance of the win, stating that the team needs to keep winning and performing to close the gap on City, who currently lead by four points.

Roma ended a four-month winless streak at home by defeating Napoli 1-0 in Serie A, with Miralem Pjanic scoring the decisive goal in the 25th minute. Goalkeeper Morgan de Sanctis played a crucial role by saving multiple shots from Napoli throughout the match. The victory moved Roma four points ahead of city rivals Lazio in the standings. Napoli's winless streak was extended to five matches, and security was tight for the match due to the recent history between the two clubs.

Doncaster Rovers had an uninspiring season in League One, finishing mid-table. Their match against Fleetwood Town ended in a 0-0 draw at Keepmoat Stadium, presenting a challenge for the media team to create a short highlight video, resulting in a 27-second clip featuring only 14 seconds of match action.

The passage describes a unique interaction between a man, Roland Giroux, and his blood parrot cichlid fish. Despite being a marine pet, the fish engages with Giroux through touch, allowing him to gently stroke and massage the fish within its tank. The fish responds by relaxing, swimming in circles, and returning to be stroked, even following the man's hand to the surface when he removes it. Initially, the fish was part of a larger tank with two other fish, but was later isolated due to bullying. Giroux feeds the fish frozen blood worms and plays with it daily, noting the fish's sociability and enjoyment of interaction. The blood parrot cichlid, a hybrid breed originating from Taiwan in 1986, demonstrates a remarkable ability to form a bond with its human caretaker through tactile interaction.

Ben Stokes, known for his fiery character in the England cricket team, broke his wrist after punching a locker in Barbados, serving as a reminder to channel his aggression appropriately. Despite a slight back niggle, Stokes is expected to play in the upcoming match in Barbados. England's coach, Peter Moores, had a productive discussion with Stokes following a clash with Marlon Samuels, emphasizing the importance of managing his aggression while maintaining his natural exuberance. England aims to have Stokes in the team as much as possible to help him reach his full potential, balancing his character with controlled aggression to contribute runs and wickets.

The Wales national football team has secured a sell-out 33,000 capacity Euro 2016 qualifier against Belgium at the Cardiff City Stadium on June 12. Both teams are tied on 11 points from five games, but Belgium leads due to a better goal difference. Wales' recent 3-0 victory over Israel has boosted their confidence, and the Football Association of Wales reports an overwhelming demand for tickets, leading to the sell-out. Despite initial speculation about playing at the larger Millennium Stadium, UEFA rules prevent a venue change within 120 days of the match date, and the Wales squad prefers the more intimate Cardiff City Stadium.

England's Under-17 squad, led by coach John Peacock, has been announced for the upcoming UEFA European Under-17 Championship in Bulgaria. The defending champions, who secured the title last year by beating Holland on penalties, have a perfect qualifying record. They will compete in Group D alongside Holland, Italy, and the Republic of Ireland, with their opening match against Italy on May 7 in Burgas. The squad features talented players from various Premier League clubs, including Chelsea's Jay Dasilva and Ike Ugbo, Arsenal's Chris Willock and Stephy Mavididi, and Liverpool's Herbie Kane and Trent Arnold, who have earned recalls after missing the Elite Round of qualifiers.

Manchester City is interested in signing 14-year-old Anderlecht playmaker Evangelos Patoulidis, who is considered one of the best talents from Anderlecht's youth system. Despite offers from Arsenal and Barcelona, Patoulidis chose to stay with Anderlecht to continue his education. City has been in talks with Anderlecht chairman Roger Vanden Stock to finalize a compensation deal for the young talent, as the club aims to build for the future.

A 33-year-old transgender escort, Vanessa Santillan, was found strangled and beaten to death in a Fulham, London flat at the end of March. A 23-year-old man has been arrested in connection with her death but has been released on bail. Police are appealing to anyone who had contact with Santillan in the hours before her death to come forward, as they continue to investigate the case.

A woman named Dawn, who has had seven miscarriages, was devastated when her family friend Jamie stole £207 set aside for her baby's gravestone. After Dawn confronted Jamie and Carol, the latter of whom was Jamie's girlfriend, a lie detector test confirmed Jamie's guilt. Dawn, who was planning to use the money to buy a gravestone for her late son Daniel James, expressed her deep betrayal and hurt, stating that the gravestone was a way to honor her son's memory.

ISIS released over 200 Yazidis, mostly women and children, who had been captured, killed, or displaced when the group overtook their towns in northern Iraq last summer. The freed Yazidis were received by Peshmerga forces and sent to the Kurdish regional capital, Irbil. The exact motivation for the release is unclear. This release follows previous ISIS releases of Yazidis, mostly children and the elderly, since their conquest of the region last year. ISIS has a history of extreme cruelty towards Yazidis, including slaughtering hundreds and raping and enslaving female captives.

Tottenham striker Harry Kane, who has had a remarkable season breaking into the first team and England's national side, is nominated for both the PFA Player and Young Player of the Season awards. A new animation by Copa90 features some of Kane's best goals and celebrations from the season, including his 20th Premier League goal against Newcastle, a long-range strike against Chelsea, a headed goal against Arsenal, and his England debut goal. The video, titled 'Harry Kane - PFA Player of the Year?', is released ahead of the awards ceremony where Kane is competing against players like Eden Hazard and Alexis Sanchez for the top prize.

Former Liverpool defender Jamie Carragher believes Brendan Rodgers is still the right man to lead the team forward despite a season with no trophies and a likely finish outside the top four. Carragher, who collected a Beacon Award for his community work on Merseyside, stated that one game should not determine a manager's future and that Rodgers, the players, and the staff should focus on improving the team and winning a trophy next season.

A four-year-old boy, James Hayward, had his plastic Nerf gun confiscated at East Midlands Airport due to security concerns, despite it being a harmless toy. The security staff, described as "over-zealous," performed a thorough pat-down and inspection of the child. James's father, Phil Hayward, criticized the security measures as "ludicrous" and questioned the thoroughness of the checks. The family, on their way to Lanzarote for a 10-day holiday, had to leave the toy behind and later purchased a replacement from eBay. East Midlands Airport apologized for the inconvenience but stated that they offered to post the toy back to the family's home in Doncaster. The airport defended their decision, citing government regulations that prohibit items resembling prohibited items, including replica or model guns.

A 31-year-old man from Humpty Doo, Northern Territory, posted an online advertisement on Gumtree seeking a girlfriend or wife who loves pets, is non-drinker and non-smoker, fit, attractive, reliable, honest, and loyal. He outlined specific requirements for his ideal partner, including being good with housework, cooking, and in bed. The man, who identifies as "Rich," described himself as athletic, heavily tattooed, independent, and wealthy. He also mentioned he enjoys the outdoors, sports, fishing, and camping. The advertisement promised benefits for the successful candidate and stated that former partners should not apply.

FA chairman Greg Dyke has received support from five former England managers, including Graham Taylor, Glenn Hoddle, Kevin Keegan, Sven-Goran Eriksson, and Steve McClaren, in his push for radical changes to increase the minimum number of home-grown players in club squads from eight to 12. The proposals also suggest changing the definition of 'home-grown' to include players who have trained in England for three years before the age of 18. The managers warn that blocking these changes could hinder England's football development and make it harder to win the World Cup, as the pool of English talent at the top level is shrinking.

In the latest episode of Poldark, Ross Poldark, played by Aidan Turner, is seen gazing lovingly at his newborn daughter, making him a popular heartthrob among fans. However, the timeline of Demelza Poldark's pregnancy, played by Eleanor Tomlinson, is criticized for being unrealistic, as she jumps from barely showing to being eight months pregnant within a short span of time, and then giving birth within minutes. This rapid progression of events has been noted by fans on social media.

Leicester City manager Nigel Pearson advises his team to maintain focus on their own games and not get distracted by relegation rivals. Leicester is currently three points from safety in the Premier League, having won their last two matches, including a dramatic 3-2 victory against West Bromwich Albion. Manager Pearson emphasizes the importance of the team's own performance in securing survival, stating that they need to ensure their run-in is managed effectively. He warns against becoming overly optimistic based on recent results.

A North Pacific gray whale named Varvara set a record by completing the longest migration of a mammal, traveling nearly 14,000 miles from her primary feeding ground off Russia's Sakhalin Island to Baja, Mexico. This journey surpassed the previous record held by a humpback whale. Varvara's route, which included three major breeding areas for eastern gray whales, suggests she may be an eastern gray whale rather than an endangered western gray whale, as previously thought. This discovery could impact the estimated population of western gray whales, which is believed to be around 150.

A 1,000ft stretch of seabed emerged overnight on Shiretoko Peninsula near Rausu, Hokkaido Island, Japan, due to a landslide caused by melting ice and snow. The new landmass, ranging from 30 to 50ft above sea level and measuring 1,000-1,640ft long and 100ft wide, surprised local residents who felt no tremors or heard any sounds indicating movement. Authorities do not expect the landslide to expand further and do not believe it is related to the recent 7.8-magnitude earthquake in Kathmandu Valley.

Gregory van der Wiel, a Paris Saint-Germain full back, has denied rumors of leaving the club in the summer, expressing his love for PSG and his teammates. He had a recent disagreement with manager Laurent Blanc over his exclusion from the Champions League match against Chelsea. Van der Wiel is committed to signing a new contract and is ready to play whenever called upon. Meanwhile, Barcelona's Dani Alves remains a potential target for PSG.

Carlos Tevez, the 31-year-old former Manchester City striker, has reportedly requested to terminate his contract with Juventus to return to his former club Boca Juniors in Argentina. Despite Juventus' reluctance to lose their top scorer, who has scored 17 goals this season, the club has started identifying potential replacements. Boca Juniors, Tevez's first club, is close to finalizing a deal for the Argentine international, who has a history with the club dating back to his youth academy days. Tevez's manager, Tata Martino, emphasizes that the player's decision to potentially move back to Boca does not affect his future with the Argentina national team.

Bayern Munich manager Pep Guardiola tore a hole in his left trouser leg during a 6-1 Champions League victory against Porto, showcasing his underwear. Despite the wardrobe malfunction, Bayern secured their place in the semi-finals with goals from Thiago Alcantara, Jerome Boateng, Thomas Muller, Xabi Alonso, and Robert Lewandowski, while Porto went into the match with a two-goal lead.

A multi-vehicle crash involving ten people, including four children, occurred on the Brisbane Valley Highway near Fernvale on Wednesday afternoon. Three vehicles collided, resulting in injuries ranging from chest and shoulder injuries to arm and abdominal pain. Three patients were airlifted to Brisbane's Princess Alexandra Hospital, while six others were taken to Ipswich Hospital with minor injuries. The highway was closed for a few hours, with diversions in place.

Arsenal midfielder Mesut Ozil excitedly showed off his new Apple Watch on Instagram, comparing it to the gadget from the TV show Knight Rider. The 26-year-old is set to play for Arsenal against Chelsea in a crucial Premier League match on Sunday, with the Gunners trailing Chelsea by 10 points. Jack Wilshere, who returned from injury, is expected to start for Arsenal, and club legend Ray Parlour believes Wilshere has the potential to be a key player for the club, provided he maintains his fitness.

Referee Mark Clattenburg will officiate the Manchester derby between Manchester United and Manchester City at Old Trafford on Sunday, despite having sent off three players from both teams this season. Clattenburg has a history of controversy but is generally regarded as one of the Premier League's leading referees. The match, which could decide the second-place finish behind Chelsea, comes at a crucial time for both teams, with United currently leading the league by a point.

Federal MP Bob Katter accused the Queensland Government of believing embattled MP Billy Gordon was a "little black puppet on a string" after Gordon was accused of domestic violence and withheld his criminal history. Katter, of Lebanese descent, defended the statement, citing his personal experiences with racist attitudes and expressing sympathy for Gordon's position. The comment sparked criticism on social media, with some questioning Katter's terminology. Katter later defended the term, stating it was based on his own experiences and to highlight the racial overtones. Gordon has since announced he will remain in the Queensland parliament as an independent, causing chaos for the government.

19-year-old Dayna Dobias from Illinois, born with cerebral palsy, is using her dancing videos to challenge stereotypes and positively influence others. Despite facing bullying and stares, Dayna aims to inspire people by showing that she is just like everyone else, doing things like driving and attending college. She hopes her videos will not only entertain but also encourage viewers to look past her disability and treat her as an equal. Dayna has also started motivational speaking at local schools to share her story and promote inclusivity.

Orlando City, an MLS team with a large Latin-American fanbase, is interested in signing Manchester United player Javier Hernandez, who is currently struggling on loan at Real Madrid. Eight European clubs, including Southampton, Stoke, West Ham, Everton, Wolfsburg, AC Milan, Lazio, and Inter Milan, are also interested in the 26-year-old. United has offered a £8 million deal for Hernandez, who has one year left on his contract. Meanwhile, Manchester United has made a revised contract offer to 19-year-old Andreas Pereira, with several European clubs showing interest in the midfielder.

A group of at least three individuals poured gasoline on a car at a 76 gas station in South Los Angeles around 12:15am on Saturday, setting it ablaze while two passengers were inside. The driver, who was pumping gas, had an argument with the suspects before the attack. The incident, which occurred around 12:15am, is being investigated as an arson by the Los Angeles County Fire Department, with the suspects still at large. No one was injured during the fire, but the car's front end was severely damaged.

Chiropractor Charles Manuel from Lamoni, Iowa, has surrendered his state license after admitting to accepting sex as payment for services and performing exorcisms on patients. He signed an agreement admitting his misconduct and pledging not to apply for reinstatement for at least 10 years. Despite this, Manuel has received positive patient satisfaction ratings on HealthGrades.com. The agreement requires him to prove that the circumstances surrounding the revocation of his license no longer exist before he can resume practicing in the state.

The United States is complaining to Russia about a recent incident where a Russian SU-27 fighter jet intercepted a U.S. RC-135U reconnaissance plane in an "unsafe and unprofessional" manner over the Baltic Sea. The Pentagon claims the Russian pilot's actions were aggressive and close to the U.S. aircraft, while Russian officials say the U.S. plane was flying with its transponder off. This is not the first such incident; a similar close pass occurred over the Sea of Okhotsk a year ago, which the U.S. also complained about to Russia.

An FBI agent's sniper rifle was stolen from a hotel parking lot in Salt Lake City just days before President Obama's visit to the city. The rifle, secured in a hard case with padlocks and chains, was taken by breaking the rear passenger-side window and using the momentum from another vehicle to remove the case. The agent's gear bag, backpack, and some clothing were also stolen. The thief broke the window frame and pulled the car door from the door, indicating the case was ripped through the shattered window. The rifle has not been recovered, and the hotel lacks surveillance cameras. The Secret Service was notified about the theft before Obama's visit, but it's unclear if it prompted increased security.

In 2012, Luigi Costa, 71, is accused of murdering his elderly neighbor, Terrence Freebody, by stomping on his head, cutting his throat, and stabbing him multiple times in their home in Red Hill, Canberra. Forensic psychiatrist Professor Paul Mullen testified that Costa likely suffered from dementia and alcohol abuse at the time of the incident, which caused his mental state to fluctuate and impair his judgment. The jury will consider Costa's unstable mindset when determining his guilt or innocence.

Everton manager Roberto Martinez defended Ross Barkley's decision to take a penalty in their 1-0 win against Burnley, despite Leighton Baines being available. Barkley, who has scored 15 penalties from 16 attempts in the Premier League, took the 10th minute kick, which he missed but didn't cost Everton as Kevin Mirallas scored the only goal after 29 minutes. Martinez stated that Barkley showed responsibility in taking the penalty and that he was happy to let the player decide based on his feelings at the moment.

Two passengers were found dead in their stateroom on the Holland America Line's ms Ryndam cruise ship in Puerto Rico, likely due to a murder-suicide, according to the cruise line. The FBI is assisting in the investigation. The ship, which departed from Tampa, Florida on March 29 on a 14-day Southern Caribbean cruise, is currently docked in San Juan, Puerto Rico.

Patrick Kluivert, a former Dutch forward and assistant coach, has successfully led Curacao to advance to the second qualifying round of the 2018 World Cup in CONCACAF. Curacao won 4-3 on aggregate after a 2-2 draw in the second leg match. Kluivert, whose mother is from Curacao, previously played in the 1998 World Cup semi-final and served as an assistant coach to Louis van Gaal last year. Curacao will face Cuba in the next round on June 8 and 16.

Esteban Cambiasso, a former Inter Milan and Real Madrid player, has expressed his desire to help Leicester City avoid relegation from the Premier League, stating that it would feel like winning a trophy. Despite Leicester's current seven-point deficit at the bottom of the table with only eight games remaining, Cambiasso remains optimistic and believes his team has a chance to save themselves. He emphasizes the importance of the task at hand, comparing it to winning a major European competition.

A 23-year-old mother of two, Gemma, faces potential loss of visitation rights to her children from her 52-year-old mother, Debbie, due to Gemma's refusal to stop drinking, partying, and suspected theft. Debbie, who has cared for the children since they were four months old, claims Gemma's behavior is out of control and that she is unfit to be a parent. Debbie suspects Gemma of stealing an iPad and other items, and is preparing to ban her from the home and preventing her from seeing the children.

In a match between Chelsea and Manchester United, Chelsea's Eden Hazard scored the opening goal after a strong challenge from Chelsea captain John Terry on Manchester United's Radamel Falcao, who lost the ball to Chelsea midfielder Cesc Fabregas, leading to Hazard's goal. Sky Sports pundits Thierry Henry, Jamie Redknapp, and Graeme Souness agreed that Terry's tackle was a foul, with Souness specifically criticizing the elbow to Falcao's head and Henry expressing sympathy for Falcao as a fellow striker.

Lady Antebellum singer Hillary Scott's tour bus caught fire on a Texas freeway due to a blown-out rear tire. Everyone on board was safely evacuated, including Scott, her husband, the tour manager, and the driver. The band's other members, Charles Kelley and Dave Haywood, were not on the bus. The fire destroyed most of the bus's back lounge, except for Scott's Bible. Lady Antebellum is scheduled to perform at the 50th Academy of Country Music Awards in Arlington, Texas.

Dr. Adrian Quarterman, a scientist from Dundee University, is developing a space laser system that converts sunlight into energy using mirrors and semi-conductors. The energy generated can be transmitted back to Earth, potentially making solar power viable in Scotland and aiding in disaster recovery. Initial trials in Scotland were successful, and Dr. Quarterman plans to expand the trials to Portugal. While the lasers will not be powerful enough to cause significant damage, there is a concern about who will control the satellites.

Stephen Munden, a 54-year-old convicted paedophile with a "fanatical obsession" with young girls, has gone missing after escaping from a psychiatric unit in Hook, Hampshire. Munden, who was detained under the Mental Health Act for sexually touching a three-year-old girl, was last seen leaving the hospital on Tuesday. He is described as 5ft 8ins tall, heavy-built, with dark hair, and may have shaved his beard. Police are conducting a manhunt to locate him, emphasizing the urgency due to his history of sexual offenses and learning difficulties.

V. Stiviano, Donald Sterling's former female companion, was ordered by a Los Angeles judge to repay over $2.6 million in gifts after Sterling's wife sued her. Shelly Sterling accused Stiviano of targeting wealthy older men and claimed Donald Sterling used their money to buy her luxury items, including a Ferrari, two Bentleys, and a Range Rover. Stiviano argued that she never took advantage of the gifts and that Sterling lavished her with them. The court decision sets a precedent for the injured spouse to recover damages from the recipient of ill-begotten gifts. Sterling's downfall was triggered by an audio recording of him making racist remarks about Stiviano and African-Americans, leading to an NBA ban, a $2.5 million fine, and the termination of his ownership rights in the Los Angeles Clippers.

Thierry Henry, speaking after Arsenal's goalless draw with Chelsea, criticized the club's recent transfer dealings and urged them to sign four key players - a goalkeeper, center back, defensive midfielder, and striker - to have a chance at winning the Premier League title. Henry also questioned whether Olivier Giroud, Arsenal's first-choice striker, can lead the team to the title, stating that Arsenal would need to replace him with a top-quality striker.

A young woman who endured years of abuse from Bega Cheese CEO Maurice Van Ryn has testified in court about the severe impact it had on her life. Van Ryn pleaded guilty to 12 sex offenses, including the most serious charge of persistent sexual abuse of a child. The victim, who remained anonymous, expressed fear for her future relationships and confusion about why she was targeted. She revealed that she didn't understand the wrongdoing at the time and only spoke up after learning of Van Ryn's arrest. The abuse has left her with depression and self-harm tendencies, and she worries about the long-term effects on her relationships with men.

Serge Gnabry, a 19-year-old Arsenal midfielder, is preparing to return to the first team after a year-long absence due to a serious knee injury. Despite not featuring in the first team since March 2014, Gnabry recently played 90 minutes for the Arsenal Under-21s against Reading. He expressed feeling "better and better" and is optimistic about his upcoming return.

Jacob Phillips, a 23-year-old accountant, died after falling down a 70ft cliff in Penarth, South Wales, during a night out with friends. Phillips, who had been out drinking in Cardiff, caught a taxi home but did not have enough money to pay the fare. He and his friends decided to run from the taxi driver, who gave chase. Phillips, disoriented in the dark, ran towards the cliff's edge and fell to his death the next day, discovered by a dog walker. The coroner recorded a verdict of accidental death, noting that Phillips likely became disoriented and was unaware of the danger he faced.

The passage describes a passport processing fiasco in the UK last summer, where thousands of holidaymakers faced delays and missed trips due to a backlog of passport applications. Despite the Passport Office making a £42 million profit, they offered limited compensation, approving only 2,191 compensation claims out of millions, resulting in an average payout of £92.68. The Home Affairs Committee chairman, Keith Vaz, expressed astonishment at the lack of compensation, especially considering the agency's significant profit.

A semi-detached home in Horfield, Bristol, built in the 1930s and left untouched for over 80 years, is up for auction with a guide price of £200,000 to £250,000. The property features original elements such as stained-glass windows, oil-fired central heating, a mint green and black bathroom with original tiles and wooden floor, and vintage cupboards. The wood-panelled hallway is illuminated by stained-glass windows depicting ships, while the living room showcases windows with coats of arms. Despite some modern upgrades like double glazing, the house's unique antique features may deter developers due to potential renovation costs. The auction is scheduled for April 30 at the County Ground in Bristol.

Colin Kaepernick started as a backup for Alex Smith but became the 49ers' starter in 2012 after Smith's concussion. He led the team to their first Super Bowl appearance since 1994, losing to the Ravens.

Anne Rice, born in New Orleans, spent her early life there before moving to Texas and then to San Francisco. Route 495 is a 3.45-mile freeway in Hudson County, New Jersey, connecting the New Jersey Turnpike to New York State Route 495, providing access to Midtown Manhattan.
Telemundo is an American Spanish-language terrestrial TV network owned by Comcast via NBCUniversal Telemundo Enterprises.

Damon Albarn, raised in Leytonstone, East London, attended Stanway School where he met Graham Coxon and formed the band Blur. Blur's debut album, "Leisure," was released in 1991. Albarn later released his solo album, "Everyday Robots," in 2014, featuring collaborations with notable artists and samples from Lord Buckley.
Mogadishu, also known as Hamar, is the capital and most populous city of Somalia, housing many important national institutions.
The passage states that "Happiness in Slavery" is a song by the American industrial rock band Nine Inch Nails, featured on their debut extended play (EP) titled "Broken" released in 1992.
Andrew Kevin Walker is an American screenwriter, born on August 14, 1964, who has been BAFTA-nominated.

The passage describes two works featuring Bob Lee Swagger: a 2007 film where Mark Wahlberg plays a Force Recon veteran framed for murder by a rogue private military company, and a TV series starring Ryan Phillippe as an expert marksman living in exile who returns to action after learning of a plot to kill the president.
The passage describes "House" (also known as House, M.D.) as an American television medical drama that aired on the Fox network for eight seasons, from November 16, 2004 to May 21, 2012.

Charles Manson was convicted in 1971 for first-degree murder and conspiracy to commit murder for orchestrating the deaths of seven individuals, including actress Sharon Tate, through his followers. He was also found guilty for the murders of Gary Hinman and Donald "Shorty" Shea. Manson's involvement led to the release of his songs commercially.

Sean Penn is an American actor, filmmaker, and political activist who began his acting career in television at age 14. He gained critical acclaim and won his first Academy Award for Best Actor in 2003 for his role in Mystic River, with subsequent wins in 2008 for Milk.

Sir Donald Bradman, known as "The Don," was an Australian cricketer considered the greatest batsman of all time. After retiring, he remained influential in the sport as an administrator, selector, and writer for three decades.
L.A. Reid has held prominent executive positions including chairman and CEO of Epic Records, president and CEO of Arista Records, and chairman and CEO of Island Def Jam Music Group.

Brad Wilk is a drummer best known for his work with rock bands Rage Against the Machine (1991-2000, 2007-2011) and Audioslave (2001-2007). He began his career in 1990 with Greta and co-founded Rage with Tom Morello and Zack de la Rocha in 1991. As of 2016, Wilk is part of the band Prophets of Rage alongside Commerford, Morello, Chuck D, B-Real, and DJ Lord.

The Millers was a multi-camera series that aired on CBS from October 3, 2013 to July 18, 2015, consisting of 34 episodes across two seasons. The show was canceled by CBS on November 14, 2014, just four episodes into its second season.

Dorothy Ann Willis Richards, an American politician and the 45th Governor of Texas from 1991 to 1995, gained national attention as the state treasurer who delivered the keynote address at the 1988 Democratic National Convention. She was the second female governor of Texas and known for her outspoken feminism and one-liners. Richards was defeated for re-election in 1994 by George W. Bush. Ann Richards, unrelated to Dorothy Ann Willis Richards, was an American jazz singer and wife of pianist Stan Kenton.
Drake Bell released an EP titled "A Reminder" independently in 2011.

The passage provides information about the 1979 American drama film "Boardwalk", written by Stephen Verona and Leigh Chapman and directed by Verona. It also mentions that Janet Leigh, an American actress, singer, dancer, and author, wrote four books between 1984 and 2002, including two novels.

Simón Bolívar, also known as El Libertador, was a Venezuelan military and political leader who led the establishment of Venezuela, Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru, and Panama as independent sovereign states from Spanish rule.
The Bermuda Triangle, also called the Devil's Triangle, is a region in the western North Atlantic Ocean where several aircraft and ships have reportedly disappeared under mysterious circumstances.

He led the team to their first Super Bowl appearance since 1994, losing to the Ravens. In his first full season as a starter in 2013, Kaepernick helped the 49ers reach the NFC Championship, losing to the Seahawks.

Advertising is a nonpersonal, mass media form of marketing communication that promotes or sells products, services, or ideas through openly sponsored, nonindividualized messages. It utilizes traditional media like newspapers, magazines, TV, radio, and outdoor ads, as well as modern media such as search results, blogs, websites, and text messages.
Private Lives is a 1930 comedy of manners by Noël Coward and a 1931 American Pre-Code comedy film directed by Sidney Franklin.
Maurice Harold Macmillan, 1st Earl of Stockton, was a British Conservative politician and statesman who served as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom from 1957 to 1963.

Aristotle, born in Stagira, Greece in 384 BC, was a renowned philosopher and scientist who studied at Plato's Academy in Athens until around 347 BC. After Plato's death, he tutored Alexander the Great upon the request of Philip II of Macedon.

David Mordechai Packouz, born on February 16, 1982, is an American former arms dealer, musician, inventor, and entrepreneur. He invented the BeatBuddy, a guitar pedal drum machine, and currently serves as the CEO of the music technology company Singular Sound.

Magic Johnson played point guard for the Lakers for 13 seasons, winning championships in high school and college, and becoming the first overall pick in the 1979 NBA draft. He won a championship and an NBA Finals MVP in his rookie season, and went on to win four more championships with the Lakers in the 1980s. After retiring for four years due to protests, he returned in 1996 at age 36, playing 32 games before retiring for the final time. Johnson is recognized as one of America's most influential black businessmen by Ebony magazine and has various business interests, including being a part-owner of the Lakers.

Tenacious D is a comedy rock duo formed in 1994 by Jack Black and Kyle Gass, releasing three albums: Tenacious D (2001), The Pick of Destiny (2006), and Rize of the Fenix (2012). They gained popularity in 1997 through their TV series and supporting large rock acts.

James VI and I, who reigned as King of Scotland from 1567 and as King of England and Ireland from 1603 until his death in 1625, was a strong advocate for a unified parliament for England and Scotland. He successfully implemented this in Scotland but encountered significant challenges in England, such as the Gunpowder Plot in 1605 and ongoing conflicts with the English Parliament.

Big Brother 2017, also known as Big Brother 18, is the upcoming eighteenth series of the British reality TV show hosted by Emma Willis and narrated by Marcus Bentley, a British actor, broadcaster, and voice-over artist known for his work on the UK version of Big Brother since 2000.

The Free State of Saxony is a landlocked federal state in Germany, bordered by Brandenburg, Saxony Anhalt, Thuringia, Bavaria, Poland, and the Czech Republic. It is the tenth largest German state by area (18,413 km2) and the sixth most populous (4 million people). Saxony has a history spanning over a millennium and is known for its quality wine production, being one of the northernmost wine regions in Europe and the only two in Germany's 13 wine regions located in former East Germany.
East End Park was a former major league baseball stadium in Cincinnati's East End neighborhood, and "In the End" is a song by the American rock band Linkin Park.
Mel B. Brown started her solo career with the release of "I Want You Back" featuring Missy Elliott on Virgin Records.
Noah Cyrus is the youngest daughter of Billy Ray Cyrus, and the younger sister of Miley Cyrus and Trace Cyrus.

The 1994 Indian action thriller film Mohra, directed by Rajiv Rai, stars Akshay Kumar, Sunil Shetty, Raveena Tandon, and Naseeruddin Shah. It was released on July 1, 1994, and became the second highest-grossing Indian film of that year, earning nine Filmfare nominations in 1995. Originally, Divya Bharti was to play the female lead, but after her death, Raveena Tandon took over the role. The film is also known for its chart-topping songs.

Shane Black, born on December 16, 1961, is an American screenwriter, director, producer, and actor, best known for writing the 1987 action film Lethal Weapon and directing his directorial debut, Kiss Kiss Bang Bang, released in 2005.

Papua is Indonesia's largest and easternmost province, encompassing western New Guinea. It was previously known as Irian Jaya (or West Irian/Irian Barat) and covered all of Indonesian New Guinea.
Augustus likely died from natural causes, though rumors suggest his wife Livia may have poisoned him.

Jennifer Lopez launched her music career in 1999 with the album "On the 6" and the hit single "If You Had My Love." In 2001, she released "J.Lo" and starred in "The Wedding Planner," becoming the first woman to have a number one album and film in the same week. Her personal life, including a high-profile relationship with Ben Affleck and marriage to Marc Anthony, influenced her music, particularly her 2002 album "This Is Me... Then." Lopez faced a low point with the 2003 film "Gigli," but rebounded with box office successes and a successful return to music in 2011 with the hit single "On the Floor."

A working animal, typically domesticated, assists humans in various tasks such as providing tractive force, milking, herding, or offering support like guide dogs. While some wild animals can be tamed and trained for work, they often lack the trustworthiness and mild temperament of true domesticated working animals.

Sancho Panza is a character from Miguel de Cervantes' 1605 novel Don Quixote, serving as the squire to the titular protagonist. He is known for his humorous, ironic Spanish proverbs, and earthy wit, which he shares as comments throughout the novel.

Viola Davis had supporting and minor roles in films like Kate & Leopold (2001) and Far from Heaven (2002), as well as the TV series Law & Order: Special Victims Unit, during the late 1990s and early 2000s.

American actor Jack Ryan Falahee, born on February 20, 1989, is recognized for his roles as Connor Walsh in the ABC legal drama "How to Get Away with Murder" and Benjamin Stringfellow in the PBS historical drama "Mercy Street."

Seohyun, born Seo Ju-hyun on June 28, 1991, is a South Korean singer and actress who debuted as a member of the successful girl group Girls' Generation in 2007. After her group's activities, she transitioned to acting, notably in stage musicals like Moon Embracing the Sun, Gone with the Wind, and Mamma Mia. Seohyun made her solo debut with the extended play "Do n't Say No" on January 17, 2017, becoming the third member of Girls' Generation to debut as a solo artist.

The Apple II is an 8-bit home computer, one of the first successful mass-produced microcomputers, designed primarily by Steve Wozniak. The Apple II series, trademarked as "Apple ] [ " and later as "Apple / / ", was introduced in 1977 by Apple Computer (now Apple Inc.) and is part of a family of early text command microcomputers.

The Freeport Doctrine, proposed by Stephen A. Douglas during the Lincoln-Douglas debates on August 27, 1858, in Freeport, Illinois, was part of the series of seven debates between Abraham Lincoln (Republican candidate for the U.S. Senate from Illinois) and Stephen Douglas (Democratic Party candidate). These debates, held in Freeport, Quincy, and Alton, attracted large crowds due to the significant importance of the slavery issue across the nation.

The passage describes the 2010 American teen comedy film "Easy A", directed by Will Gluck and written by Bert V. Royal. The film stars Emma Stone and features a cast including Stanley Tucci, Patricia Clarkson, Thomas Haden Church, Dan Byrd, Amanda Bynes, Penn Badgley, Cam Gigandet, Lisa Kudrow, and Aly Michalka.

American author Anne Rice, born Howard Allen Frances O'Brien in 1941, is known for gothic fiction, Christian literature, and erotica. She gained popularity in the 1980s with her Vampire novels and was married to poet Stan Rice for 41 years until his death in 2002.

Camden is a city in Camden County, New Jersey with a population of 77,344 as of the 2010 census, making it the 12th most populous municipality in the state. Historically, the city's population in the early 20th century was primarily composed of European immigrants.
Bret Easton Ellis is an author who wrote the screenplay for the 2013 film "The Canyons," an erotic thriller-drama directed by Paul Schrader.

The Lincoln-Douglas Debates, also known as The Great Debates of 1858, were a series of seven debates between Abraham Lincoln, the Republican candidate for the United States Senate from Illinois, and Stephen Douglas, the incumbent Democratic Senator. The debates took place in seven Illinois towns.

The passage identifies Homer as the author of the Iliad and Odyssey, central works of ancient Greek literature, and introduces The Thicket, a mystery/suspense novel by American author Joe R. Lansdale.
Christopher Scott Kyle, a United States Navy SEAL and sniper, was murdered on February 2, 2013, by Eddie Ray Routh at a shooting range near Chalk Mountain, Texas.

The passage describes the rock band Audioslave, formed in 2001, which consisted of Soundgarden lead singer Chris Cornell and Rage Against the Machine members Tom Morello, Tim Commerford, and Brad Wilk. Brad Wilk, known for his drumming in Rage Against the Machine and Audioslave, started his career with Greta in 1990 and co-founded Rage with Tom Morello and Zack de la Rocha in 1991. As of 2016, Wilk is also part of the band Prophets of Rage.

Janelle Monaé Robinson, born December 1, 1985, is an American singer, songwriter, actress, and model signed to Wondaland Arts Society and Atlantic Records. She released her critically acclaimed first full-length studio album, The ArchAndroid, in 2010, a concept album sequel to her first EP, which was originally released by Bad Boy Records.
Winter's Tale is a 1983 novel written by Mark Helprin.

Lake Providence is a town in East Carroll Parish, northeastern Louisiana. It is the parish seat and has a University of Mississippi affiliation. About 55% of undergraduates and 60% of the student body come from Mississippi, with 23% being minorities and international students from 90 nations.
The passage states that the series was renewed for a six-episode second season, set to premiere on June 2, 2017.

Aaron Burr served in various political roles, including twice elected to the New York State Assembly, appointed New York State Attorney General, chosen as a U.S. senator from New York, and reached the peak of his career as Vice President.

The Soyuz rocket, commissioned by the Soviet space program, launched both unmanned and manned Soyuz spacecraft. It was designed by the Korolyov Design Bureau and remains in service today, succeeding the Voskhod spacecraft and originally intended for Soviet lunar programs.
Steve Ditko studied under Batman artist Jerry Robinson at the Cartoonist and Illustrators School in New York City.

Rage Against the Machine disbanded in 2000 due to growing tensions, with lead vocalist Zack de la Rocha quitting and forming a solo career. The remaining members formed Audioslave with Chris Cornell. In 2007, Rage Against the Machine reunited and performed at Coachella. Their fourth album, "Renegades," was released in December 2000.

The S&P BSE SENSEX, also known as the BSE 30 or SENSEX, is a free-float market-weighted stock market index of 30 well-established and financially sound companies listed on the Bombay Stock Exchange. Tata Motors is one of these constituent companies, being listed on the BSE, the National Stock Exchange of India, and the New York Stock Exchange.

Vietnam, officially the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, is the easternmost country on the Indochina Peninsula in Southeast Asia, with an estimated 92.7 million inhabitants. It is the world's 14th-most-populous and ninth-most-populous Asian country. Vietnam shares borders with China, Laos, Cambodia, Thailand, the Philippines, Malaysia, and Indonesia. Since 2000, Vietnam has had one of the highest economic growth rates globally, ranking highest among 11 major economies in 2011. The country officially espouses communism as a one-party socialist state.
Dreamer is a 2005 American sports drama film written and directed by John Gatins, marking his directorial debut.

Bhagat Singh was a charismatic Indian socialist revolutionary who committed acts of violence against British in India and was executed at 23, becoming a folk hero of the Indian independence movement after his death.
Aparshakti Khurana made his Bollywood debut in the 2016 Indian Hindi-language biographical sports drama film "Dangal," directed by Nitesh Tiwari, which is about a wrestling competition.

James VI and I, born on June 19, 1566, was King of Scotland from 1567 and King of England and Ireland from 1603 until his death on March 27, 1625. He ruled the kingdoms of Scotland and England in a personal union, each with their own parliaments, judiciary, and laws. James advocated for a single parliament for England and Scotland but faced challenges with Parliament during his reign in England.

Danielle Cormack is a New Zealand stage and screen actress, known for her roles in the soap opera Shortland Street, Xena: Warrior Princess as Ephiny, The Cult as Cynthia Ross, Legend of the Seeker as Shota, the 2009 film Separation City, the Australian series Rake, and the Foxtel drama Wentworth as Bea Smith.
Rob Sheridan is an American graphic designer, director, and photographer, best known for his work with the band Nine Inch Nails.

David Spade is an actor who has starred and co-starred in films such as Tommy Boy, Black Sheep, Joe Dirt, Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser, Grown Ups, and Grown Ups 2. Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser is a 2015 American comedy film directed by Fred Wolf and written by David Spade and Fred Wolf.
Angela Evelyn Bassett is an American actress, born on August 16, 1958.

The passage discusses the album "Artpop" by Lady Gaga, which received mixed reviews from critics but was commercially successful. It debuted at number one on the US Billboard 200 with 258,000 first-week sales, becoming Gaga's second consecutive number-one record in the US. The album sold 757,000 copies in the US alone and was the ninth best-selling album worldwide in 2013, with 2.3 million copies sold globally.
John Frusciante released his fifth and final album with the Chili Peppers, Stadium Arcadium, in 2006, marking the group's last album featuring him, who departed in 2009.
Margaret Thatcher, as Prime Minister, implemented policies known as Thatcherism, making her one of the most influential and controversial figures in British political history.

Michael Andrew "Duff" McKagan is an American musician, singer, songwriter, and author born on February 5, 1964. He has a successful musical career and also writes weekly columns on various topics for SeattleWeekly.com, Playboy.com, and ESPN.com.
Tom Baker, an English actor, has pursued acting roles and also worked as a narrator for commercials, video games, audiobooks, and television series.

Valencia, the capital of Spain's autonomous community of Valencia, is the third largest city in Spain with approximately 800,000 inhabitants. It is part of the larger Valencian Community, which has a population ranging from 1.7 to 2.5 million.
Buffy Summers was portrayed by Kristy Swanson in the film and later by Sarah Michelle Gellar in the television series.
The passage states that the TV series "Make It or Break It" was announced to end on April 26, 2012, with the third and final season airing on May 14, 2012.

Speech recognition is an interdisciplinary field that combines linguistics, computer science, and electrical engineering to develop methods and technologies for converting spoken language into text using computers. Applications include voice user interfaces, call routing, domotic appliance control, search, data entry, preparation of structured documents, speech-to-text processing, and aircraft communication. Advances in speech recognition are driven by the surge of academic research and industry adoption of deep learning methods by companies such as Google, Microsoft, IBM, Baidu, Apple, Amazon, Nuance, SoundHound, IflyTek, and CDAC.

Richard Alf, an American businessman and former comic book store owner, co-founded San Diego Comic-Con International in 1970 and served as its chairman from 1970. The convention, initially called the Golden State Comic Book Convention, later became known as the San Diego Comic Book Convention.
The passage is a brief summary stating that "Fist of Legend" is a remake of the 1972 film "Fist of Fury," with Bruce Lee reprising his role as the lead character.

France's Dubuisson tied with South Africa's Van Zyl at 16 under par after a 67, while McIlroy moved to 15 under par with a 67, including an eagle on the 12th. McIlroy, aiming for his first title since May, expressed confidence in his performance and believes a low round is possible.

Sheikh Ali Salman, leader of the al-Wefaq opposition group in Bahrain, emphasizes the need for a meaningful national dialogue that includes concrete solutions from the government. He sees Crown Prince Salman al-Khalifa as a reformist who could lead such dialogue, despite opposition from hardliners, including the unelected Prime Minister. Sheikh Salman believes dialogue is necessary and that the only way forward is to work with reformists within the royal family. He criticizes the UK government for not publicly pressuring Bahrain to end violence and human rights abuses, and calls for the release of 13 opposition leaders and human rights activists unjustly imprisoned.

Christopher Hogwood, a renowned conductor and founder of the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973, passed away at his home in Cambridge following an illness that lasted several months. Hogwood, who was considered one of the most influential exponents of the early-music movement, worked with many leading orchestras worldwide and directed the AAM across six continents for 30 years. He made over 200 CDs, including the first complete cycle of Mozart symphonies on period instruments, and his recording of Handel's Messiah with Emma Kirkby was named one of the top 20 recordings of all time by BBC Music Magazine. Hogwood studied at Cambridge University and held positions at the Academy of Saint Martin-in-the-Fields, the Early Music Consort of London, and Harvard University. He was also a tutor at Harvard, an honorary professor of music at the University of Cambridge, and a professor-at-large at Cornell University. Hogwood was known for his generosity, intelligence, and dedication to historically informed music.

In the year ending March 2016, Scotland recorded its lowest number of homicide cases since 1976, with 57 victims. This represents a five-case decrease from the previous year and half the number from nine years ago. Sharp instruments, particularly knives, were the most common method of killing, accounting for 51% of homicides. Alcohol and drug influence were factors in 31% of cases. Justice Secretary Michael Matheson emphasized the need for continued efforts to prevent violent crime, while Scottish Labour's justice spokeswoman Claire Baker cautioned against premature celebration, citing concerns about sexual crime and rising violent crime rates.

The Cherries lost 2-1 to Sunderland in the Premier League, marking their first defeat to Sunderland this season. Dan Gosling scored the only goal for the Cherries, their first in three games. Manager Mike Howe expressed disappointment, stating the team had created numerous chances but failed to capitalize, emphasizing the importance of moving on from the loss.
