Trust chairman Rob Rees emphasized the potential of school meals to encourage children to try new foods and increase dietary variety. Mumsnet co-founder Carrie Longton noted that children often feel pressure to fit in and try new foods at school. School meals in England must meet strict nutritional guidelines, with about 40% of primary school children and 46% of secondary school children in England eating school lunches. Scotland has a higher rate, with around 46% of children eating school lunches.

Morata, a 23-year-old striker, joined Juventus in 2014 from Real Madrid with an option for Real to buy him back, reportedly for up to 30m euros. He has scored 27 goals in two years for Juventus, winning two Serie A titles and two Coppa Italias. Morata has also played for Spain at Euro 2016, scoring three times in France. He made his Real Madrid debut at 18 and scored 10 goals for the team.

Wilson returned to Championship club Forest from Celtic for £2.5m in 2013, but has been without a team since May 2017. The 30-year-old played 51 games in his second Forest spell, following four seasons with the club earlier. Wilson has also played for Preston North End and Notts County.

Tesco, the world's third largest retailer, is planning to dispose of its loss-making US food chain, Fresh & Easy, by transferring 4,000 of its 5,000 employees to a new business. Tesco will provide a £80m loan to the new business and will incur a £150m cost to dispose of the Fresh & Easy brand. If the new business becomes profitable, Tesco has the option to buy a stake. Yucaipa, a Los Angeles-based private equity company, will manage the remaining 50 stores, which will be closed.

The passage describes an individual who initially faced racial abuse but overcame it. They briefly considered representing France but are now focused on achieving a medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics. The passage also mentions a guide for those interested in getting into martial arts.

The passage discusses the significant retreat of glaciers in the French Alps over the past 40 years, from approximately 375 square kilometers in the late 1960s to about 275 square kilometers in the late 2000s, representing a 26% loss. This trend is part of a broader pattern of glacier retreat observed in other Alpine regions across several European nations. The research, led by Marie Gardent from the University of Savoie, utilized historical maps, satellite imagery, and aerial photographs to assess the condition of roughly 600 glaciers in the Ecrins, Belledonne, Vanoise, Ubaye, and Grande Rousse Arves massifs, as well as the Mont Blanc Massif. The study highlights that the retreat is more pronounced in the southern sectors of the Alps, with glaciers in the Belledonne and Ecrins massifs showing particularly severe reductions. Factors contributing to this disparity include lower elevations and different climatic conditions in the southern Alps, such as higher precipitation and cloud cover. The northern Alps, including the famous La Mer de Glace glacier, have experienced less dramatic retreat. The findings underscore the ongoing challenges in monitoring and assessing glacier health across the Alpine region, with similar trends reported in Switzerland.

Scotland's women's national team, currently unbeaten in their qualifiers, aims to secure a spot in the 2017 Women's World Cup by winning their upcoming match against ranked 20th-ranked Iceland at Falkirk Stadium. Victory would all but guarantee their place, as the outcome of this match and the return fixture in Reykjavik on September 20th will likely decide the group's top spot. Scotland's goalkeeper, Gemma Evans, emphasizes the emotional significance of reaching the finals, having previously missed out on major competitions in Euro 2013 and the 2014 World Cup. The team benefits from having players who have experienced top-tier leagues, such as Evans' time at Bayern Munich, which she believes enhances the national team's performance.

Stuart Campbell, a former computer games reviewer and Scottish independence campaigner, was arrested in the west of England on allegations of online harassment made by a woman in south London over a two-year period. Campbell, who was released on bail, denied the allegations, stating that the tweets in question were not threatening. He accused the media of using innuendo to encourage speculation. Campbell, known for his blog Wings Over Scotland, has been bailed pending further inquiries and is expected to be released in mid-September.

PETA is advocating for the replacement of Skegness's iconic Jolly Fisherman mascot with a more animal-friendly version, citing concerns about the image the current mascot conveys of animal cruelty. The original Jolly Fisherman poster, commissioned in 1908, has long been a symbol of the Lincolnshire resort. While the mayor of Skegness, Carl Macey, acknowledges the popularity of Jolly and the potential for resistance to change, he ultimately suggests the matter will be considered by the council.

Scotland dominated possession and territory in their match against Georgia, scoring six tries in the first half to lead 38-11. The Scots scored through Tommy Seymour, a penalty try, Sean Maitland, Stuart Hogg, Hamish Watson, and Moray Low. Georgia managed to score two tries in the second half, but Scotland's defense held strong, resulting in a final score of 38-17 in favor of Scotland.

Widnes Vikings defeated Castleford Tigers 38-12 in a league match, with tries from Macgraff Leuluai, Ah Van, Chris Bridge, Paddy Flynn, Lloyd White, and Joe Mellor. Despite Castleford scoring three tries in quick succession, Widnes held on to secure a 26-point lead. However, a late defensive lapse allowed Castleford's Larne Patrick to score, leading to a nervy finish. Castleford suffered their fourth consecutive home league defeat, while Widnes moved above Wakefield into seventh place.

Fawzi al-Odah, a 37-year-old Guantanamo detainee, was released after a US review panel found he was not a "continuing significant threat". He had been held at the US facility in Cuba since 2002, after his arrest in Pakistan on suspicion of links to al-Qaeda and the Taliban. Odah, who denies the charges, challenged America's right to detain him in the US Supreme Court. He will now face at least a year at a militant rehabilitation center in Kuwait. This release brings the total number of inmates at Guantanamo to 148, and marks the first inmate release since May, when five Taliban detainees were exchanged for US Sgt Bowe Bergdahl.

The passage describes the rise of the infectious and catchy song "PPAP" (Pen-Pineapple-Apple-Pen), performed by DJ Piko-Taro, a fictional character played by Japanese entertainer Kazuhiko Kosaka. The song, with its simple lyrics and dance routine, quickly gained popularity on YouTube and Facebook, amassing millions of views. Its unique and bizarre concept, along with Piko-Taro's distinctive wardrobe, contributed to its viral success. While some users find it irritating, others have created numerous tributes and covers, with many Japanese stars also participating. Despite its international appeal, the song has not been widely covered in mainstream Japanese media.

Anzac Day commemorations in London involved a large early morning service at Hyde Park Corner, a parade with up to 400 participants, and a wreath-laying at the Cenotaph. The service honored the sacrifices of Australian and New Zealand forces in World War One, particularly the Gallipoli campaign. The event included services at Westminster Abbey, singing of national anthems, and speeches by the Australian high commissioner, reflecting on the courage and heroism of the Anzac troops.

Scott Clarkson, 30, has joined Premiership Well for a second spell and could make his St Mirren debut in the Championship against Alloa on Saturday. Clarkson scored nine goals for Dundee last season and has been fit throughout the current term. He has made nearly 400 senior appearances and has one international goal for Scotland. St Mirren is currently eighth in the Championship, seven points ahead of Alloa. Clarkson is eager to get started and contribute to the team's push up the table.

The turkey firm was sold to food tycoon Ranjit Boparan, addressing concerns that his new ownership would not honor the existing workers' pension scheme. Unite regional officer Steve Harley confirmed productive talks and guarantees that all current agreements, including the Bernard Matthews final salary pension scheme, would be maintained under the new ownership. Boparan's private investment confirmed that the current pension arrangements would continue, with the aim of restoring Bernard Matthews to a highly profitable business through increased investment, cost savings, and utilizing spare capacity for processing chicken.

The passage discusses issues with a new ferry crossing at Cowes, which is set to be free until July 2nd to allow feedback. The ferry has faced problems such as breaking down, running aground, and being suspended due to training issues. These issues have caused delays, vehicle damage, and significant loss of trade for local businesses. Council leader Dave Stewart has ordered a review by auditors and is open to discussing compensation for affected businesses. Transport councillor Ian Ward sees the ferry as a prototype with expected teething problems and has authorized ramp extensions to address vehicle scraping issues.

The House of Lords European Union Committee's report on the UK fishing industry post-Brexit highlights the risks and opportunities for the industry. While the industry only contributes 0.5% to GDP and employs 12,000 people, it must not be marginalized in Brexit negotiations. The Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) has been criticized for disadvantaging Britain, but Brexit presents a chance for the industry to regain control over UK waters and become a leading fish-exporting nation. However, the report warns that EU member states may demand more access to UK waters, potentially leading to four different fisheries management regimes. The industry argues that Brexit will bring more opportunities than threats, with the EU recently announcing new quotas under the CFP, which are seen as favorable for the UK. The government emphasizes the importance of ensuring British companies have maximum freedom to trade in the single market while reviewing fisheries management for fair access to quota and sustainable stocks.

Timothy Geaney admitted to taking or permitting images of young boys between 2004 and 2014, leading to a community payback order, registration as a sex offender, and removal from his teaching profession following a General Teaching Council Scotland hearing. The panel found his actions incompatible with being a teacher, noting a pattern of behavior and lack of remedial action, ultimately deeming him unfit to teach and prohibiting him from re-registering for two years.

The passage describes a fire at a waste recycling site in Duncan Street that occurred on March 2nd, disrupting train services and causing travel delays. The Environment Agency suspended Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited, the site operator, from accepting waste following the incident. The fire service noted that the company had generally complied with fire safety regulations. GMFRS visited the site nine times in the past year, expressing concerns about the potential impact of a fire on nearby residents, transport, and the environment. The EA decided to revoke the company's environmental permit, effective August 7th, unless the company appeals the decision. The company must still remove all waste from the site. The cause of the fire remains unknown.

Syria is struggling to meet the deadline for destroying its chemical weapons stockpile, having missed a recent deadline and reported two shipments being intercepted by terrorist groups. Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad attributes the delays to the ongoing war and criticizes US condemnation of Syria's use of barrel bombs. The Syrian government denies reports of rebels seizing Aleppo's central prison, while the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights claims rebels have taken control of the prison, holding at least 3,000 detainees. Syria has about 1,300 tonnes of declared chemical weapons, with only 4% transferred so far. The US and Russia have expressed concerns about the slow progress of the UN-backed plan, with Russia urging Syria to complete the transfer by March 1.

England secured a crucial series-leveling victory at Old Trafford, with Joe Root named man of the match for his outstanding performances in both innings. Root scored 254 runs in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 in the second, while also taking four catches and a wicket. England's total of 589-8 declared and 173-1 declared set a new record for their biggest win over Pakistan. Root's controlled batting and disciplined performance helped England overcome Pakistan's weak batting display, which yielded only 234 in their first innings. Despite the win, England's coach Trevor Bayliss believes the series will remain tight, with Pakistan showing potential for improvement.

Older People's Commissioner for Wales, Sarah Rochira, is conducting a review of the quality of life and care for older people in residential care across Wales. She aims to gather evidence from pensioners, their friends, families, care providers, and public bodies to develop recommendations for care providers and public bodies. Rochira will highlight both good care practices and the impact of poor care on older people. The review will assess factors such as physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment. However, the chair of Care Forum Wales, Mario Kreft, expressed disappointment that no provider expert or individuals with lived experience of care homes are included in the advisory panel, which he believes would enhance partnership working and sector engagement.

Former Aberdeen midfielder Sheerin, 39, has been appointed player-manager at Pittodrie, replacing Neil Cooper. He joins after Aberdeen's chief executive, Duncan Fraser, completed a thorough selection process. Sheerin, who previously managed Arbroath to their first national trophy in 2011, played for various Scottish clubs and Östersunds in Sweden before transitioning into coaching. He earned a Scotland Under-21 cap in the mid-1990s.

Swansea City will appoint a new manager, Curtis and assistant manager Paul Williams taking charge after Bob Bradley's sacking. Ex-Derby manager Paul Clement is the first choice. The club aims to appoint someone who can help them avoid relegation, as they were promoted to the Premier League in 2011 and have struggled to maintain their position. The current squad is believed to be good enough to stay up, but the club has lost key players and experienced management.

Dr. Craig Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur, transformed the mapping of the human genome into a competitive race, earning him criticism from the scientific community for his modesty and wealth. After the human genome's publication, he shifted focus to creating a synthetic life form, resulting in the development of Synthia, an organism published in Science. Born in 1946, Venter initially pursued surfing in Southern California before joining the Vietnam War, which instilled a sense of urgency and a commitment to medicine. His medical training led him to the US National Institute of Health, where he recognized the potential of automated decoding machines to accelerate gene sequencing. Leaving the NIH in 1992, Venter founded The Institute for Genomic Research and later Celera Genomics in 1995, which announced the first complete genome of a free-living organism, Haemophilus influenzae. In 1998, he formed Celera Genomics to complete the human genome in three years, a project that published its results in 2001. Despite controversy over his methods and disregard for scientific conventions, Venter's financial success allowed him to pursue his scientific goals independently. In 2006, he established the J Craig Venter Institute to create the world's first synthetic life form. Venter's work has also included oceanographic projects to sequence microbial genomes from the sea, aiming to advance understanding of gene and protein functions and potentially revolutionize industrial processes.

The passage discusses a report by the Sutton Trust warning that many apprenticeships in England are of low quality and too short, with fewer than 200,000 out of 520,000 starting annually rated at level three (A-level equivalent). Only 20% of employers in England offer apprenticeships, compared to 51% in Germany, which has a highly regarded vocational education system. The report suggests that England should increase apprenticeships to 300,000 annually, with most being at level three for at least three years. It criticizes the current system as confusing for employers and undervalued by society, and calls for improvements in vocational courses, careers advice, and guidance. The Department for Education acknowledges reforms to improve apprenticeship standards but faces challenges in creating more places, especially for younger apprentices.

British Paralympian Sarah Storey won a cycling race in Nottwil, Switzerland, finishing over two minutes ahead of Poland's Anna Harkowska. At 37, Storey, Britain's most decorated female Paralympian with 22 medals, is targeting further success at the 2016 Rio Paralympics. She has won 11 gold, 8 silver, and 3 bronze medals in cycling and swimming across six Paralympics, including 4 golds at the 2012 London Games and 21 world titles in total.

The passage describes Hereford United's expulsion from the Conference Premier due to financial difficulties, despite efforts to keep them in the league. The club faced debts of £148,000 and failed to meet a deadline to pay their creditors, leading to their expulsion. Chester City, taken over by London businessman Tommy Agombar, will replace Hereford in the Conference Premier following a dramatic final day of the season.

Sam Allardyce, a former Manchester City player, has a career spanning 61 caps for England, with his debut in 2009. He was a squad member for two World Cups and two European Championships, but only played three minutes at Euro 2016. Milner holds the record for the most capped England Under-21 player, with 46 appearances since 2004. He scored his only international goal in England's 5-0 victory over Moldova in the 2014 World Cup qualifiers.

Christopher Hogwood, a renowned conductor and founder of the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973, passed away at his home in Cambridge following an illness that lasted several months. Hogwood was a key figure in the early-music movement, having worked with numerous leading orchestras worldwide and directing the AAM across six continents for over 30 years. He made more than 200 CDs, including the first complete cycle of Mozart symphonies on period instruments, and his recording of Handel's Messiah with Emma Kirkby was named one of the top 20 recordings of all time by BBC Music Magazine. Hogwood studied at Cambridge University and held positions at the Academy of Saint Martin-in-the-Fields, the Early Music Consort of London, and Harvard University. He was known for his generosity, intelligence, and dedication to historically informed music, leaving a lasting legacy in the field.

The passage describes a family from Northern Ireland with a son who has special needs. Due to privacy concerns, his family is not naming him. His mother had to quit her job to care for him. In June, they removed him from mainstream school due to his inability to cope. They applied for a spot at a special school but are still waiting as all schools in the area are full. The family is concerned that this situation may affect other families due to the high demand for special needs school places. The Education Authority is reviewing the demand for special school places in Northern Ireland, aiming to provide places closer to the children's homes starting in 2016. However, they cannot comment on individual cases due to privacy laws.

The Newport Gwent Dragons rugby team is facing a takeover bid from the Welsh Rugby Union, who see Rodney Parade as a rugby venue. The Dragons have a lease to use the ground until 2023, with priority fixtures if they remain in the Football League. The WRU's takeover will be voted on by shareholders in early May. The Exiles agreed to the 10-year lease in 2013 after promotion to the Football League. Newport RFC chairman Will Godfrey states that both County and the Newport Squash Club are protected under their current agreements. The WRU plans to install an artificial surface, which is against Football League rules. Newport County is currently two points clear of relegation in League Two, with two games remaining. A potential relegation to the National League would be devastating for the fans and the city of Newport.

The passage recounts the author's experiences during the Sierra Leone civil war and subsequent Ebola crisis. Kidnapped at 15 and trained by the Revolutionary United Front (RUF), the author endured brutal treatment and witnessed horrific acts. After escaping, he lived alone in Freetown, eventually joining a rehabilitation project led by Richard Cole, which inspired him to pursue education and rebuild his life. When the Ebola outbreak hit in 2014, the author, lacking medical training, initiated a community-based response, educating people about the virus, providing food and shelter, and eventually establishing an Ebola treatment unit. These efforts saved numerous lives, and the author now views his life as transformed, emphasizing the importance of investing in young people to shape a better future.

A public fundraising campaign successfully raised the necessary funds to prevent the auction of 80,000 pieces of art, ceramics, manuscripts, letters, and photographs belonging to Waterford Wedgwood plc, which were intended to pay off the company's pension debt. The collection, which holds significant cultural value for Staffordshire, will remain on display at the museum in Barlaston and then be gifted to the Victoria and Albert Museum before being loaned to the Wedgwood Museum. Administrator Bob Young expressed satisfaction with the outcome, attributing it to the goodwill and determination shown during the negotiations.

Dan Groves revealed that the details of a potential deal for Wright to acquire 20% of the club, including Wright becoming a club director, have not been disclosed yet. Billericay, currently eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, is three points behind a play-off position. The club, recently acquired by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, has signed former England international Paul Konchesky.

Mark Carney, the Governor of the Bank of England, surprised many by announcing he would extend his term by one year, rather than the originally planned departure in 2018 or the full eight-year term. This decision was influenced by personal factors, particularly the need to be present for his children's final years of schooling in the UK, as well as the ongoing Brexit negotiations. Carney emphasized that this decision was entirely personal and not influenced by political pressure or criticism regarding the Bank's economic forecasts.

In a closely contested match, Blackpool and Colchester United ended the game tied at 1-1. Blackpool took an early lead through Jamille Matt's close-range finish, but Colchester equalized shortly after through Kurtis Guthrie. Despite several chances, neither team managed to secure a winning goal. The game ended with Colchester playing with 10 men after Sean Murray received a red card for violent conduct.

The Healthy Me program, developed by Northern Ireland charity Action Mental Health, aims to help children in P6 and P7 cope with the transition to secondary school by teaching them about emotional wellbeing, encouraging them to seek help if needed, and providing teachers with basic training in promoting emotional wellbeing. The program consists of interactive workshops and has been piloted in five schools, with the goal of being rolled out across Northern Ireland. The transition from primary to secondary school can be stressful for both children and parents, as they face changes in the educational environment and increased academic pressure. The program aims to strengthen resilience in young people, as modern life can impact mental health and hinder learning.

The passage describes plans to convert the disused Fawley Power Station chimney in Southampton, England, into a 198-meter-tall glass structure, becoming the tallest such attraction south of London's Shard. This would be the centerpiece of a £1bn "merchant city" development featuring a marina, housing, restaurants, and fast ferry links to Southampton and Portsmouth. The power station, commissioned in 1971, was 2,000 megawatt oil-fired and powered one million homes. The site, previously sold to developers in 2016, could see construction begin in 2018 if outline planning permission is granted later this year.

British cyclist Adam Latham won bronze in the men's points race at the Hong Kong championships, following GB's second medal of the event with Elinor Barker's silver in the women's scratch race. Latham chased down Poland's Adrian Teklinski and Germany's Lucas Liss to secure the bronze. GB's men's team pursuit team finished third behind Italy, while British keirin rider Joe Truman was outclassed in the semi-finals. The women's team pursuit team finished fifth in the heats and failed to make the bronze-medal ride.

Dame Barbara, played by Ross Kemp, returns to EastEnders for her final episodes after a 10-year absence, revealing her cancer has returned. She tells her eldest son Phil, played by Steve McFadden, that she will die from the disease. Kemp, who previously played Grant Mitchell from 1990-1999 and then again in 2005 and 2006, will reunite the Mitchell family, including his brother Phil, for the last time. The return of the Mitchell brothers is significant as they face the loss of their mother, showcasing strong performances from Kemp and McFadden.

Sadio Mane scored twice in 138 seconds, leading to Tottenham's disappointing performance at Anfield. Manager Pochettino criticized the team's lack of desire to win, stating that Chelsea could extend their lead at the top if they beat Burnley. Spurs have only won twice away from home since September, and in their past 17 away meetings with top-six teams, they've won only once. The Argentine manager emphasized the need for improvement, particularly in handling pressure and maintaining consistency against top opponents.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of the 28 governorships in Nigeria's recent elections, marking a significant defeat for the previously dominant Peoples Democratic Party (PDP). This is the first time the PDP has lost the presidential election, with APC leader Muhammadu Buhari set to be inaugurated as president on May 29. The PDP's decline is evident in their loss of key northern states and control of Adamawa, a state affected by Boko Haram insurgency. However, they retained Rivers State, Nigeria's oil hub. The PDP only won eight governorships, mostly in the south-east. The APC's victory is notable as they failed to win in Nigeria's five oil-producing states, which could be a concern for Buhari due to potential oil disruptions. The elections were generally more peaceful than previous years, but violence and ethnic conflicts occurred in some areas. The PDP will need to undergo introspection and rebuild under a new leader.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival, HebCelt, will take place in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from July 19-22. Visitors can use an app to access online content like videos, band interviews, and updates via augmented reality, enhancing their festival experience. The festival features acts such as The Waterboys, Imelda May, and Dougie MacLean. The augmented reality feature also allows global viewers to interact with the festival and experience its atmosphere remotely.

The passage discusses the termination of funding agreements for three Birmingham academies, Park View and Nansen Primary, and Oldknow Academy, due to being rated inadequate by Ofsted. The head teacher of one of the Trojan Horse schools reported that parents tried to undermine her authority during an Ofsted inspection. The watchdog published 21 reports into schools allegedly targeted in a hardline Muslim takeover, with five of those schools rated inadequate. Birmingham City Council will work with Saltley School and the Department for Education to install a temporary governing board at the only local authority school placed in special measures. The education minister, Lord Nash, criticized the trusts for failing to promote the spiritual, moral, social, and cultural development of pupils and set out a list of actions the trusts must take before July 4 to address the issues. Ofsted chief Sir Michael Wilshaw stated that a culture of fear and intimidation has taken hold in Birmingham schools, with head teachers reporting an organized campaign to impose a narrow, faith-based ideology.

Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe, a 38-year-old British-Iranian woman, was sentenced to five years in prison in Iran for allegedly plotting to overthrow the government, though the charges remain undisclosed. Her husband, Richard Ratcliffe, criticized the UK government for its lack of action and expressed concern over the secretive nature of her appeal hearing in Tehran. Mrs. Zaghari-Ratcliffe has been in solitary confinement since her arrest at Tehran Airport in April, with her two-year-old daughter, Gabriella, remaining in Iran and being cared for by her grandparents. The family has been left in uncertainty about the outcome of the appeal, which could result in her sentence being quashed, reduced, or increased. Richard Ratcliffe believes his wife is being used as a bargaining chip in a diplomatic dispute between Iran and the UK.

Vincent Barker, known as Vinnie, died in July 2012 after a routine eye test at Boots in Ipswich. The prosecution claims that optometrist Honey Rose, 35, failed to detect Vinnie's swollen optic discs and refer him for further investigation, which led to a build-up of fluid in his brain, increasing pressure in his skull and ultimately causing his death. The court heard that Rose's conduct was so far below the expected standard of a competent optometrist that it was "criminal." Rose denies the charge of gross negligence manslaughter, and the trial continues.

Clive Weatherhogg, 42, was found guilty of coercing a woman into sexual activity and intercourse with a man he introduced through an adult website, and filming the encounter. He also sent a sexually explicit message to the victim's sister on Christmas Day. Weatherhogg was placed on the sex offenders register and remitted to the High Court for sentencing due to its greater powers. The judge emphasized the societal abhorrence of his actions and assessed him as a moderate risk for future sexual re-offending.

Ireland's T20 team scored 165-5 against Afghanistan in Greater Noida, with Stuart Thompson's 56 runs, Gary Wilson's 41, and William Porterfield's 39 contributing to the total. Despite a competitive score, Ireland fell short of the target as Afghanistan reached 171-4 with two overs to spare, thanks to Samiullah Shenwari's 56 and Mohammad Shahzad's 47. The match will be repeated on Friday. Afghanistan's victory was bolstered by Shahzad and Najeeb Tarakai's 51-run opening stand, while Afghan spinner Amir Hamza took 2 wickets. Ireland's loss of paceman Boyd Rankin due to a back problem was another setback, but he is expected to return for the upcoming five ODIs against Afghanistan starting on 15 March.

Barcelona insists they did not commit any offense regarding the tax payment for Neymar's transfer. The club paid £48.6m for the player, with his parents receiving £34m. The total cost, including wages, agents fees, and this latest tax payment, is estimated at £106.8m. Barcelona has made a tax declaration of 13.55m euros to defend their reputation, but the case is still under investigation.

UK detectives have completed their investigation into the murders of Hannah Witheridge and David Miller on a Thai beach, and will now return to the UK to compile a report and update the families' findings. The two Burmese suspects, Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Htun, are charged with conspiracy to murder, conspiracy to rape, and robbery, and could face the death penalty if found guilty. The UK Foreign Office expressed concerns about the investigation, particularly regarding DNA verification and allegations of mistreatment. Post-mortem examinations revealed Miller died from drowning and a head blow, while Witheridge died from head wounds; DNA found on Witheridge matched samples from the suspects.

Virtual reality (VR) is being increasingly used as a tool by various professionals, including journalists, teachers, healthcare workers, and retailers, to provide a more immersive understanding of the world. For instance, the UK's National Autistic Society created a VR film to help people understand autism better by simulating the sensory overload experienced by an autistic individual in a shopping center. Similarly, Alzheimer's Research UK produced a VR film to show the challenges faced by people with dementia in performing everyday tasks. VR is also being used in the retail sector, such as by IKEA, which launched an app that allows users to virtually place furniture in their homes. In healthcare, VR is being used for teaching purposes and to treat phobias, such as helping soldiers with post-traumatic stress disorder and aiding arachnophobics in overcoming their fear of spiders. Additionally, VR is being explored for educational purposes, with apps like Evanescent Studios' Mandarin language learning tool and Google's Expeditions program, which takes students on virtual field trips. However, challenges such as affordability and the need for adequate hardware and computing power may hinder the widespread adoption of VR in schools.

The passage describes the opening of the "black box" from a downed Su-24 jet in Moscow, which could help resolve disputes over its location when it was shot down by Turkish F-16 fighters on November 24. The incident has strained relations between Russia and Turkey, with Moscow imposing sanctions. Turkey claims the jet ignored warnings to leave its airspace, while Russia asserts it was within Syrian airspace. Both crew members ejected, but the pilot was killed by militants, and a Russian marine and helicopter were also lost. Russia demands an apology from Turkey and has imposed economic sanctions.

Scotland's women's national soccer team has won all five qualifiers so far and will host Iceland at Falkirk Stadium on Friday, with victory likely securing their spot in the finals. Captain Kim Evans, who recently won the women's Bundesliga with Bayern Munich, emphasizes the importance of this match, noting that a loss would be devastating after previous play-off losses. The outcome of the match and the return fixture in Reykjavik on September 20 will likely determine the group's top spot. Scotland is in a strong position to reach the finals in the Netherlands next summer without a play-off, as the best six of the eight group runners-up qualify automatically. Evans highlights the benefits of having players in top leagues, both for the national team and her own development, as the Scottish league continues to improve.

The passage discusses a review by a commission on local tax reform in Scotland, which found that the council tax system, while stable and difficult to avoid, has inherent problems from its inception. The commission, set up by the Scottish government and council body Cosla, will report back later in the year. While a property tax is considered a "good tax" by academics due to its stability and ability to impact housing markets, it generates confusion among taxpayers and is perceived as unfair by some. A local income tax, seen as fairer by many, creates difficulties for local authorities due to fluctuating income. The commission concludes that there is no "magic bullet" for reform, noting that past experiences show reform is difficult and tied to previous reform traumas. The Scottish government, considering the current council tax system unfair, has established the cross-party Commission on Local Tax Reform to explore fairer alternatives, with a public consultation planned before the report is published in the autumn.

The passage discusses a security measure implemented by Apple to prevent the theft of intimate photos from iCloud, which were allegedly stolen using third-party software. The new two-step verification system requires users to enter a four-digit code sent to their trusted device or via Apple's Find My iPhone app after entering their username and password. This additional step aims to block unauthorized access to iCloud accounts. However, the security feature remains an opt-in choice, with some experts suggesting it should be the default option. Apple has acknowledged that its software, Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker, may have been used in the recent hacks, but claims the new security measures now prevent this technique. The passage also highlights concerns about the recovery key's usability and potential risks, while another expert recommends making two-factor authentication the default setting for enhanced security. Apple has stated its intention to encourage users to enable two-factor authentication and use stronger passwords.

The passage provides campaign expenditure figures for the 2014 European elections in the UK. UKIP spent £2,956,737 per vote at 68p, Labour spent £1,027,339 at 26p, the Conservatives spent £2,980,815 at 79p, and the Lib Dems spent £1,580,575 at £1.45 per vote. The Green Party spent £534,249 at 43p per vote. The SNP's spending was £267,372. The six highest-spending parties collectively spent £9,347,087, with all parties except Labour spending more than their 2009 campaign expenditures.

Centre-back Anderson, 27, is leaving Barrow by mutual consent to join Gillingham, his National League rivals, with a potential appearance against his old club on February 18. Striker Keating, 21, has joined Gillingham after being recommended by ex-Port Vale manager Micky Adams, with his move pending international clearance. Gillingham, currently four points above the relegation zone, have won only one of their last six games.

A 10-year-old Irish-bred horse named Many Clouds collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day. The British Horseracing Authority confirmed the cause of death as a "severe pulmonary haemorrhage," a rare incident that can occur in healthy horses across all disciplines. Despite Many Clouds' history of post-race ataxia and overheating, the horse had no prior symptoms on the day of the race. The racing community is determined to understand the causes of such incidents and prevent them in the future.

The passage describes the emotional farewells of three prominent Scottish politicians - Presiding Officer Tricia Marwick, former First Minister Alex Salmond, and Scottish Labour MSP Duncan McNeil - as they stand down ahead of the May 5th election. Salmond, who served as First Minister from 2007-2014, emphasized Scotland's unity and diversity, welcomed increased powers to Holyrood, and joked about competition from the Cheltenham racecourse. Marwick thanked Salmond for his contributions and acknowledged the parliament's responsibility to learn from Westminster. McNeil warned of the need for accountability and scrutiny in Holyrood's committee system, noting that the parliament must be capable of meeting this challenge.

The passage announces a 2017 film adaptation of Beauty and the Beast, starring Emma Watson as Belle, Dan Stevens as the Beast, and Kevin Kline as Maurice. Mrs. Potts will be played by Meryl Streep, and Gaston and LeFou by Dan Stevens and Josh Gad, respectively. The film, directed by Bill Condon, will be released in US cinemas on March 17, 2017, and begins filming at Shepperton Studios in May.

The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) will meet with victims' relatives to discuss potential charges in relation to the 1989 Hillsborough disaster, where 96 football fans died. The meeting, set for 11:00 BST, will cover evidence related to 23 suspects, with 15 cases tied to the Operation Resolve investigation and 8 to an Independent Police Complaints Commission probe. Margaret Aspinall, whose son died, hopes the meeting will lead to complete accountability for the tragedy. The families, invited to a private meeting in Warrington, await the CPS's decisions with mixed emotions, determined to never give up in their pursuit of justice.

Chelmsford Prison has reported numerous incidents of packages being thrown over its walls, with residents and former inmates describing it as "flooded" with mobile phones and synthetic cannabis. The Ministry of Justice stated that staff are working hard to prevent contraband from entering prisons, but more needs to be done. The Justice Secretary has tasked the Ministry to explore ways to equip prisons to handle such issues. A local resident reported witnessing packages being thrown over the wall four times in two weeks, expressing concern but not fear. The Ministry confirmed there is no evidence of drones being used to bring contraband into the prison, and laws now allow for up to two years in jail for those caught smuggling packages over prison walls.

Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady, suffered serious head injuries when she was struck by a car driven by Brian Wright, 55, in Kempston last December. Wright, who claimed he was blinded by the setting sun, admitted hitting Mrs. Blackburn but denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving. The court heard that Wright's VW Golf failed to stop at a red light, despite traffic in the opposite direction stopping. Wright expressed deep remorse, stating he understands Mrs. Blackburn was a beloved lollipop lady and is truly sorry for the impact on her and her family. The trial continues.

Middle distance runner Eilish Muir, who finished fourth and sixth in the 1500m and 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships, will miss the 2022 Commonwealth Games in April due to her veterinary medicine studies. She expressed disappointment at missing the event, which is a significant opportunity for Scottish athletes. Muir remains optimistic about her future, stating she has at least two, possibly three more Olympics in her career. She is currently focused on her studies and aims to compete in the World Indoor Championships in March.

Trevor Deely, 22, went missing after a Christmas party in December 2000. A search in Chapelizod, Dublin, began on Saturday, involving excavations over three acres of woodland near the R112. CCTV footage from the night of his disappearance shows Deely talking to a man in black outside the Bank of Ireland, where he worked, and later being followed on Haddington Road. The man in the footage has not been identified, and detectives renewed their appeal for him to come forward, expecting the search to take several weeks.

Del Potro, who has been out of the sport for over two years due to injury, secured a 3-6, 6-3, 7-6 (7-2), 6-3 victory over Switzerland's Stan Wawrinka at Wimbledon. The Argentine, ranked 165th, will next face either Lucas Pouille or Donald Young. Del Potro, 27, is playing in his first Grand Slam since 2014 after three wrist operations. He expressed joy at returning to competitive tennis and praised the crowd's support. Meanwhile, Nick Kyrgios, also in the same half of the draw as Andy Murray, defeated Germany's Dustin Brown in a rain-affected match, advancing to the third round where he will face Feliciano Lopez. Other notable victories include Tomas Berdych and Jo-Wilfried Tsonga.

Tunisia faced expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations but apologized to CAF for complaints lodged against the organization. Morocco joined the qualifying draw after Cas overturned a ban on its participation. Tunisia and Morocco are preparing for a future full of good things for both Africa and Morocco. The Tunisia Football Federation never accused CAF or the referee of corruption, but claimed the referee was poorly chosen. Tunisia's participation was uncertain until a meeting with CAF president Issa Hayatou in Senegal, leading to a resolution of their differences.

McLaren, a team with a rich history of 182 Grand Prix wins and multiple championships, is currently experiencing a significant decline in performance, often finishing in the lower grid positions. Despite this, the team still boasts two world champions in the cockpit, including Fernando Alonso, a key figure in their resurgence. The slump began in 2013 due to issues with chassis design, but the team has recently shown improvement with their car, though the problems lie with their Honda power unit. McLaren's history is marked by cycles of triumph and decline, with their last constructors' title won in 1998. The team's current predicament is seen as a temporary setback, with McLaren's current team principal, Ron Dennis, confident that success will return, potentially breaking Mercedes' dominance in Formula 1.

On 6 October 2014, paramedics were called to Joe's Bar in Dungiven following a sudden death. Police found several people still at the bar, with till receipts showing alcohol was served until 04:49 BST. Colleen O'Neill, 43, and James Thomas, 44, both from the same address, were charged with allowing liquor consumption outside licensing hours. The judge ordered the bar's closure for three months, citing an "appalling record" and expressing concern over the lack of strict adherence to licensing laws. O'Neill was fined £3,000, while Thomas was fined £1,000.

Stephen Curry broke his own NBA three-point record by making 272 three-pointers in a single season, scoring 45 points and adding nine assists in the Golden State Warriors' 116-105 victory over the Portland Trail Blazers. Curry's eight three-pointers helped the Warriors come back from a 13-point deficit, and teammate Klay Thompson contributed 26 points. The Portland Trail Blazers, who have already secured the Northwest Division, had 27 points from Lamarcus Aldridge and 20 points from Damian Lillard.

YouTube star Bas van Velzen, known for his free-kick skills, arrived at Liverpool's Melwood training ground, leading Liverpool players Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert, and Lazar Markovic to believe he was a competition winner. However, van Velzen showcased his impressive dead-ball abilities in front of the Liverpool stars, impressing Balotelli and Lambert. Van Velzen, a YouTube sensation, had a great experience meeting the Liverpool players and pretending to be less skilled, while Balotelli wore his famous t-shirt from a past match against Manchester City.

The passage discusses a study indicating that women diagnosed with breast cancer caused by the BRCA1 gene, like actress Angelina Jolie, can significantly reduce their risk of death by having their ovaries removed, a procedure known as an oophorectomy. Women with BRCA1 mutations face a high risk of both breast and ovarian cancer, with a lifetime risk of breast cancer up to 70%. The study found that oophorectomy reduced the risk of breast cancer death by 62% in BRCA1 mutation carriers, and a 65% reduction in overall mortality. The protective effect of oophorectomy was evident immediately after diagnosis and lasted for 15 years. The authors recommend further research, particularly on women who undergo the procedure within a year of breast cancer diagnosis, and for those with the BRCA2 variant.

A married couple, Derek and Tina Lowe, were killed in North Carolina when an Amtrak train hit them on the tracks shortly before 10 AM on Easter Sunday in Durham. The train, traveling from Charlotte to New York City, had 166 passengers on board, none of whom were injured. The Lowe's were reportedly seen collecting scrap metal and asking for help, suggesting they may have lived in a homeless camp. The train was delayed for about three hours after the accident before continuing its journey.

Carlos Toro, a 66-year-old former DEA informant who spent 27 years working undercover for the Medellin Cartel, is facing deportation from the United States after retiring. Toro, who was one of the DEA's most important assets, helped carry out undercover stings worldwide and provided crucial information that led to the prosecution of ex-panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega and cocaine overlord Carlos Lehder. He was promised U.S. citizenship in exchange for his work but has not received it, leaving him technically living in the U.S. illegally. Toro's fears are justified, as he stated he would be dead within four hours if deported back to Colombia. The DEA refused to assist him with his citizenship, and he remains in limbo while trying to obtain a green card or passport.

The US Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers (ICANN) is investigating a Canadian company, Vox Populi Registry Ltd., for potentially illegal actions related to its new ".sucks" domain name service. This service allows trademark holders and celebrities to purchase domain names that attack brands or individuals, with prices starting at $2,499 per year. Notable victims include Kevin Spacey, Taylor Swift, YouTube, Bing, Visa, Bank of America, and Yahoo. ICANN initially approved the ".sucks" domain but is now reconsidering after industry groups raised concerns about it being a "shakedown scheme" and "predatory." The company behind ".sucks" claims its business is within ICANN's rules and the law.

In 1988, a mother of a stillborn baby was arrested for infanticide after her baby's body was found in a Sainsbury's bag floating in a village pond in Norfolk. After 27 years, DNA evidence led police to her, who explained that she had concealed her pregnancy and placed the stillborn baby in the pond. The baby was reburied at St Peter's Church, and the mother remains on bail while the CPS decides on charges for failing to register a birth and preventing a lawful burial. Police ruled out foul play, and the case was closed after using advanced DNA techniques to identify the mother.

In 2010, taxi driver Michael Young mistakenly believed Kristopher Hicks was planning to "do a runner" and drove him back to the taxi rank, leading Hicks to jump out of the moving car at over 20mph. Hicks suffered severe brain injuries, developed epilepsy, and requires round-the-clock care. Hicks' family took Young to the high court, where a judge ruled Young unlawfully imprisoned Hicks and ordered him to pay compensation. The exact amount is yet to be decided, but it is expected to be around 50% of the family's requested sum, potentially hundreds of thousands of pounds. The judge acknowledged Hicks' entitlement to damages for specialist rehabilitation and care to maximize his progress.

Tornado sirens sounded in Kansas on Wednesday night as multiple storms produced reports of twisters, with one tornado reported 6 miles northwest of Goddard, near Wichita. The storm moved northeast, missing the city but posing risks to surrounding areas. CNN severe weather expert Chad Myers warned of more storms throughout the night, emphasizing that nighttime tornadoes are the most deadly. Reports of tornadoes also came in from southwestern Kansas, including near Aetna, 125 miles southwest of Wichita. Kansas was not the only state affected; a possible tornado touched down in Potosi, Missouri, about 70 miles from St. Louis, causing wind damage and flooding. Aerial footage showed damage to roofs and streets overtaken by water. Unusual dark clouds were reported in nearby Shyler and Christin Strube's Leadington. On Thursday, more storms were expected in the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the Southern Great Lakes.

Luke Rockhold, aiming for his fourth consecutive victory, is set to face Lyoto Machida in a middleweight bout in New Jersey. Rockhold, who has a title shot in his sights, believes he can dominate Machida by being the "bull" to Machida's "matador," exploiting Machida's weaknesses and maintaining control throughout the fight. Despite mutual respect between the fighters, Rockhold is confident in his ability to outmaneuver Machida and secure a win, potentially earning him a title shot.

The passage describes a shocking incident captured in Fort Pierce, Florida, where a light general aviation aircraft touched down on a runway without deploying its landing gear, skidding along the runway on its belly. The video shows the plane touching down with a bump, propellers ricocheting off the ground, and bouncing up and down from the impact. The pilot, Chris Georgaklis, managed to regain control, re-engage the engines, and take off back into the air. The plane's propellers were damaged in the collision, and the pilot later crashed 100 miles away in Fort Lauderdale, landing safely. The incident highlights the common cause of gear-up landings, which is often due to human error. The FAA is investigating the incident.

Manchester City midfielder Yaya Toure has faced criticism for his underwhelming performances this season, leading to Manchester City manager Manuel Pellegrini admitting his disappointment. However, Pellegrini has vowed to support Toure until the end of the season, despite Manchester City's struggles and the possibility of offers for Toure. Toure, who has two years left on a £220,000-a-week deal, has been urged by teammates to take responsibility for the team's poor form. West Ham United manager Sam Allardyce has warned one of his players, Aaron Cresswell, not to move to Manchester City, citing Cresswell's mistake of joining other English clubs.

Domenico Rancadore, a Sicilian mafia fugitive known as the "Godfather of Uxbridge," will be allowed to remain in the UK after his sentence was dropped. Rancadore, who has lived in Britain for over 20 years, was convicted in Italy in 1999 for his role in the mafia but was never extradited due to his long residence in the UK. His case expired in October last year, and his European arrest warrant is to be withdrawn. The Italian Supreme Court will still hear the case, but Rancadore's solicitor is confident that the extradition request will be withdrawn, allowing him to live peacefully in England with his family.

Mr Mole, ridden by Ap McCoy, has been named a co-favorite (7-2) in the Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown on Saturday, alongside Irish Raider Special Tiara and Nicky Henderson's Sprinter Sacre. Ap McCoy and Mr Mole will face six rivals in the race, which will be McCoy's last as a professional jockey, as his book of rides for his final day will not be finalized until Friday morning. The news of McCoy's retirement came after he won Mr Mole at Newbury in February. Other runners in the race include Mick Channon's Somersby.

Virginia Trimble Ritter, whose daughter Marcia was murdered by Jerome Sydney Barrett in 1975, recently decided to view crime scene photos of her daughter's body after declining to do so for decades. The photos revealed the horrific state of Marcia's body, which was found 33 days after her disappearance. Ritter now expresses a desire for revenge and regrets her previous decision not to see the photos. Barrett, who was convicted of second-degree murder in 2009, was found guilty after DNA evidence matched his to clothing found on Marcia's body.

Rory McIlroy, the world number one golfer, believes it is "unthinkable" that he will not win the Masters at some point to complete the career grand slam, joining a select group of players who have won all four major titles. The 25-year-old tees off at the Arnold Palmer Invitational in Orlando on March 19. McIlroy's final-round collapse at Augusta National in 2011 was the most important day of his career, leading him to learn valuable lessons about himself and his game. He is determined to achieve his first green jacket and complete the grand slam, viewing Augusta National as a sanctuary where he can focus on playing without distractions.

This week featured a variety of trending stories, including rainbows appearing in the New York area after heavy rain, a fashion CEO capturing the moment; exotic dancers being hired for Chinese wake ceremonies before a government crackdown; Johnny Depp's transformed appearance in "Black Mass"; a 102-year-old woman reenacting her prom experience; a school controversy over a bomb-themed prom-posal; and various other viral trends and notable events.

The passage reports alarming figures from the UK, revealing that 272 children were hospitalized last year due to brain damage caused by their mothers' alcohol consumption during pregnancy, a condition known as fetal alcohol syndrome (FAS). While this number is significant, experts warn that the actual number of affected children could be much higher, with the World Health Organization estimating that at least one in 100 babies born in the UK may suffer from learning, behavioral, and physical problems due to prenatal alcohol exposure, equating to approximately 7,500 cases annually. Elizabeth Mitchell, from the National Organisation for Fetal Alcohol Syndrome, emphasizes the under-diagnosis and tragic nature of this issue. The passage also highlights the case of 15-year-old Niamh Brown, who, due to her mother's alcohol use during pregnancy, suffers from severe developmental delays and will never live independently. The government advises pregnant women to avoid alcohol consumption, recommending no more than two units per week if consumed.

Shaun Andrew McKerry, a 31-year-old ex-juvenile offender known as "Boomerang Boy" or "Homing Pigeon Boy" for his repeated return to crime, attempted to rob a Shildon post office and stores in County Durham on March 15. When confronted by the owner, Sab Dhillon, and his wife Sam, McKerry was tackled to the ground by Dhillon, while Sam helped subdue him by hitting him twice with a baseball bat, causing him to drop the axe. McKerry, who had a history of 80 arrests by age 15 for various crimes, including shoplifting and burglary, was arrested by the police and sentenced to six years in prison.

Four Royal Navy sailors accused of gang raping a young woman at a Canadian barracks party must remain in Nova Scotia until their trial. They appeared in court in Dartmouth, Nova Scotia, where bail conditions included living at the nearby Stadacona naval base, surrendering their passports, and continuing to work for the Royal Navy while drawing their current pay. The alleged assault occurred on April 10 after the sailors returned from a hockey game. They are charged with sexual assault causing bodily harm and group sexual assault, which carry up to 14 years in prison. The investigation is ongoing, and additional charges may be brought based on forensic test results.

The passage describes the story of RJ Jackson, a four-year-old boy suffering from Netherton's syndrome, a rare congenital skin disease that causes his skin to appear red and scaly. RJ's mother, Valerie Jackson, was shocked when a stranger reported her to the police for child abuse, mistaking RJ's skin condition for signs of abuse. The incident highlights the ignorance and cruelty of some people towards RJ, who faces taunts and bullying from others due to his condition. Despite the challenges, Valerie and her husband, Reginald, have to regularly apply creams to RJ's skin to alleviate his symptoms and have faced discrimination, such as being denied entry to play centers. Netherton's syndrome is a rare genetic condition affecting one in 200,000 births, with no known cure, but symptoms often improve over time.

Campaigners against Protein World's "Are you beach body ready?" adverts are celebrating as Transport for London (TFL) confirms the removal of the controversial posters from London Underground stations. The posters, featuring a bikini-clad model, have sparked outrage among feminists and body image campaigners, with over 50,000 signatures on a petition calling for their removal. The Advertising Standards Authority has received more than 200 complaints, citing an unhealthy body image. Protein World has defended the campaign, claiming it is unphotoshopped and aimed at promoting a healthier lifestyle. The company's boss, Richard Staveley, stated that the ad is not meant to offend and is targeted at health-conscious individuals. The removal of the posters comes as a protest in Hyde Park gains momentum, with hundreds expected to attend.

The passage discusses fare hikes planned by rail firms, particularly First Great Western (FGW), just ten days after the general election, despite party leaders promising to freeze prices. FGW's decision to increase fares by up to 87% on routes through Prime Minister David Cameron's Witney constituency has angered constituents, leading to Cameron's personal intervention. The planned increases, set to take effect on May 17, include an 87% hike on off-peak return fares from Charlbury to London and a 24.5% increase on a first-class single ticket from Crewe to Northampton. FGW claims the hikes are to align the North Cotswolds route with other services, while offering cheaper advanced single tickets. Other rail firms, like Virgin, have also announced fare increases, mostly affecting their own train-only fares, which are generally cheaper than those offered by competitors.

Former soldier John Young, 66, and his newlywed wife Elaine, 54, were targeted by vandals in Oldham, leaving Young blinded in one eye after a brick was thrown through his front door. The attack occurred just three weeks after their wedding, and despite emergency surgery, doctors were unable to restore Young's vision. The couple, who have no children and met 14 months ago, are now too scared to live in their neighborhood and plan to move to Southport. Police launched an investigation but found no clear motive, suggesting the incident may have been a case of "yobs messing around."

Tom Poynton, the 25-year-old Derbyshire wicketkeeper, has signed a new one-year contract extension after successfully returning from a leg injury sustained in a road accident that also claimed his father's life. Poynton, a former England Under-19 international, missed the entire 2014 season due to an ankle operation but made his comeback during Derbyshire's pre-season tour in Abu Dhabi. Derbyshire's elite performance director, Graeme Welch, praised Poynton's exceptional character and hard work during his recovery, expressing hope that the new contract will boost his confidence and allow him to perform well this summer.

A five-year-old boy, Harley Renshaw, who was diagnosed with an aggressive form of neuroblastoma affecting his kidney, neck, lungs, and bones, has been declared cancer-free after a year-long battle. Harley's bravery during his treatment, including creating a superhero mask to help him feel stronger during radiotherapy, caught the attention of hospital staff and even earned him a box of Ninja Turtle presents from Nickelodeon. Harley's parents, Oliver and Stacey, are overjoyed with the news and hope he will soon return to school full-time.

Tim Sherwood advises Jack Grealish to prioritize his Aston Villa career over his international ambitions, as he is currently at the center of a tug of war between the Republic of Ireland and England. Sherwood believes Grealish's performance for Villa is the key factor in his options and emphasizes the importance of Grealish making the decision himself, similar to the situation with Nabil Bentaleb. Grealish is expected to choose between the two countries at the end of the season.

Private jet travel involves significant landing fees at various airports, with some unexpected hubs charging high fees. Salzburg, Austria, and Darwin, Australia, are among the most expensive, charging £2,530 and £3,059 respectively. Tokyo's Haneda and Narita airports are the most expensive globally, at £4,559 and £3,728. The passage highlights that private jet travel is a growing trend, with 2.5 million private flights in the US and 705,000 in Europe in 2013, and that landing fees can reach thousands of dollars per landing.

The passage describes a video of a Labrador named Cooper, owned by Katie Gallegos, who runs a dog resort in Clackamas County, Oregon, eating an ice cream cone from a McDonald's drive-thru in one bite, while his female companion Daisy takes only a few licks. Despite some viewers finding the scene cute and hilarious, others have criticized Gallegos for feeding the dogs the treat. Gallegos defends her actions, stating that Cooper is an athletic dog in excellent health and that he has an ice cream about once a week, similar to how her dog Sammy used to. The video has garnered over seven million views. The passage also mentions that Daisy, the smaller dog, gets only a few licks due to her size, and the pair has a penchant for fast food, as seen in another video where they visit Starbucks for a "pup-uccino."

Kilmarnock interim manager Gary Locke has been appointed to a permanent role with a three-year deal. Locke, previously Hearts' assistant boss, took over as the main manager in February after Allan Johnston left. Since then, he has won only one game out of seven. Locke will announce his permanent appointment at a press conference on Friday.

A Florida mother, Jessica Kemp, is accusing a school of threatening to suspend her five-year-old autistic son, Logan, due to the essential oils he uses to manage his condition. Teachers at Seminole County Elementary claimed the oils, produced by Doterra, smelled and distracted other students. Kemp, who applies the oils to Logan's neck to help him stay calm and focused, argues that the oils are a natural remedy and have a positive impact on her son. Despite the school's threat, Kemp plans to continue fighting the decision, and the Lake County School District later stated they would not suspend Logan, citing it as a "health issue." The family uses essential oils with scents like lavender, chamomile, and sandalwood.

A beach-side apartment complex in Westhampton, New York, known as the Sandpiper complex, was completely destroyed by a fire on Wednesday afternoon. The intense blaze, which melted paint on nearby buildings, spread through 90 condos before collapsing. The cause of the fire remains unknown, but it is being investigated. Twelve fire crews attempted to control the flames but were unable to enter the buildings. Residents, including Janice Sklarek and her partner Rob Taber, lost everything in the fire. The complex, which is used as a holiday home between May and November, was fortunately located downwind of the fire, allowing for better visibility and firefighting efforts.

The passage describes Queen Elizabeth II, aged 88, enjoying a ride on her black fell pony, Carltonlima Emma, in Windsor Great Park. Despite never wearing a riding helmet, she has been known to ride without one, preferring a silk scarf. The Queen, an avid equestrienne, has bred various horse and pony breeds, including fell and highland ponies, at her Windsor stables and Balmoral. Fells, originally used as pack animals by the Carvetii and Romans, have been a popular choice for riding since the 1950s due to their gentle nature and appealing appearance. The Queen continues to be a familiar sight at her stables, taking an active interest in her horses and ponies, some of which are now ridden by her grandchildren.

A dispute between two Brisbane neighbors over noise levels escalated to tragedy when 28-year-old Phillip Pama was charged with manslaughter for allegedly killing 55-year-old Leon Yeaman with a single punch during an argument in front of their homes. Pama, a shift worker, was reportedly sleeping when Yeaman was making noise around 9 PM on Thursday. Pama's defense lawyer stated that Yeaman was known for loud music and aggressive behavior, and that Pama acted blindly in the confrontation. Pama, a married father of three, was granted conditional bail with restrictions including surrendering his passport, adhering to a curfew, and reporting to the police station twice a week. The case is set to return to court on May 18.

A 52-year-old Russian music teacher, Yulia Simonova, was arrested after attempting to hire a hitman to torture and murder her 15-year-old ex-student, Damian Vanya, who had ended their relationship. Simonova, who had given the teen gifts and money for a year, wanted the boy to suffer and bleed to death before being "finished" with. Police set up a sting operation, filming the exchange with a hidden camera. Simonova, who faces 15 years in prison for attempted murder, expressed hope that she would receive a long prison sentence.

Chelsea football manager Jose Mourinho revealed that he prays to God every day for personal matters, but never discusses football or the game with his wife. He emphasizes the importance of separating his professional and personal life, and despite his strong faith, he claims to be a good person who supports others and tries to avoid mistakes in his professional and personal life. Currently, Chelsea is leading the league and will play against QPR this weekend.

Bob Barker, who hosted "The Price is Right" for 35 years until 2007, made a surprise return to the show on its April 1 episode, hosting the first game of the show. Despite being away from the program for eight years, Barker appeared energetic at 91 and seamlessly took over hosting duties before passing them back to Drew Carey.

An off-duty Secret Service agent, Arthur Baldwin, was arrested in Washington D.C. on Friday morning around midnight for allegedly attempting to break into a house and destroy property. Baldwin, who was posted to the foreign missions branch of the agency, has been hit with felony charges and had his security clearance revoked. He was placed on administrative leave. This arrest, along with a recent allegation of misconduct by a high-ranking supervisor, has brought further scrutiny and black eyes to the agency responsible for protecting the President and his family. The Homeland Security Department's inspector general is currently investigating both incidents.

Freelance photographer Atif Saeed, 38, from Lahore, Pakistan, risked his life to capture an image of a hungry lion from just 10 feet away in a safari park. Armed only with a camera, Saeed crept towards the lion, but the shutter sound alerted the animal, forcing him to quickly retreat. Saeed recounted the incident, expressing both awe at the lion's character and a reluctance to repeat the dangerous encounter.

The New York City Police Department (NYPD) has released an image of a tattoo found on the body of an unidentified woman who died in Brooklyn last month. The woman, believed to be between 25 and 45 years old, was found unconscious on March 22 near Shore Parkway and 26th Avenue in Gravesend. Despite efforts by paramedics, she was pronounced dead that evening. The distinctive tattoo, featuring the name "Monique" within a heart topped with a rose, was found on her right leg. The woman had no identification on her, and investigators are awaiting a medical examiner's report to determine the cause of death. Anyone with information about the unidentified woman is urged to contact NYPD Crime Stoppers at 800-577-TIPS.

A New Zealand couple, Hannah and Alex, built a solar-powered two-bedroom home on the back of a 1986 Hino flatbed truck after returning from the UK in 2009. Unable to afford a full-sized lot, they spent a year and a half constructing the cozy, wood-lined home, which features a wood-fired stove, stained glass windows, and is powered mostly by solar panels. The couple now lives in the home, surrounded by nature, and is nearly self-sufficient, with water sourced from a nearby spring. The project cost approximately $25,000, and the couple plans to build another similar home in the future.

The passage discusses a study finding that children who share iPads in class perform significantly better in early literacy tests compared to those who do not share or use their own devices. The research, conducted by Courtney Blackwell at Northwestern University, involved 352 students in a midwestern suburban school district. Blackwell suggests that collaborative learning around the technology, rather than just the collaboration itself, is the key factor contributing to the improved literacy scores. She recommends that schools reconsider how tablets are used, particularly in earlier grades, to maximize the effectiveness of the technology.

A two-legged piglet born with missing back legs has become an internet sensation after learning to walk on its front trotters, despite wobbling and near-tips. The heartwarming video, featured on People's Daily Online, shows the piglet, nicknamed "Super Pig," balancing and foraging with its snout to the ground. The unique animal, belonging to farmer Ms. Duan from Qionglai City in Sichuan Province, China, has attracted villagers and gained popularity among tourists visiting the region.

During the inaugural Indycar Grand Prix of Louisiana, tire changer Todd Phillips was struck by Francesco Dracone's car on lap 25, causing Phillips to be injured and taken to the infield care center for treatment. Phillips received stitches for a cut on his leg but was later released. Many cars faced traction issues due to rain before the race, and Dracone did not finish, ending up 23rd.

A husband, Milton Vieira Severiano, brutally murdered his dancer wife, Cicera Alves de Sena, by smashing her head into concrete 11 times and shooting her in the face 5 times, allegedly due to jealousy of men looking at her. The incident was captured on CCTV in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. Severiano confessed to the crime and now faces life in jail.

Journalist Sarah Wilson, author of "I Quit Sugar," shares her personal struggle with mental illness, revealing she nearly took her own life due to severe anxiety. She attributes her feelings to mounting stress, anxiety, thyroid disease, and feelings of isolation. Wilson emphasizes the link between depression and anxiety, urging society to better address the growing issue of stress and anxiety among Australian women.

In November 2014, Elena Curtin, a seven-month pregnant woman from Portland, Oregon, was charged with second-degree assault after she beat her boyfriend's ex-girlfriend with a crowbar after finding her using heroin in the bathroom. Curtin was set to go to trial, but prosecutors dropped the charge in January 2015, stating that she was "completely justified in her outrage." The ex-girlfriend had a history of harassing and threatening Curtin, stealing from her, and attempting to drag her boyfriend back into addiction. Curtin gave birth to their child in January 2015. If convicted, she faced a mandatory prison sentence of almost six years.

Gemma, a pit bull, was filmed being fed treats at her home in California, but her owner tricked her by adding a broccoli spear. The dog initially showed disgust and spat out the vegetable, suggesting she may not be a fan of broccoli. The passage also mentions that Gemma enjoys sleeping and spending time with her human family.

HSBC apologized after a link on its official website, hsbc.com.hk, directed visitors to a pornographic page. The issue arose because the page for the Young Entrepreneur Awards, which was shut down in 2011, had its registration transferred to the HSBC website. HSBC removed the hyperlink from its main website and issued an apology, stating that they are not associated with the external site and that their website remains secure.

A 13-year-old Maryland boy, Marcus, called 911 during a fire at his home in Clinton, calmly providing instructions to rescue himself and his 9-year-old sister, Aaliyah, who were trapped in a second-floor bedroom. Despite his sister's fear, Marcus reassured her and guided firefighters to their location through the back hallway. Prince George's County firefighters entered the room via a broken window, with Lt. Kenny Ward handing Aaliyah a gas mask. Both siblings were taken to Children's Hospital with non-life-threatening injuries, while the other three family members escaped on their own. Marcus's heroic actions were praised by Assistant Fire Chief Alan Doubleday.

Amazing pictures show blue fluorescent algae lighting up Australia's east coast, particularly in Jervis Bay on the south coast of New South Wales. Photographer Andy Hutchinson described the sight as a "beautiful supernatural scene" caused by millions of plankton emitting light. This phenomenon, caused by the single-celled phytoplankton Noctiluca scintillans, occurs naturally and is more common in spring and autumn. Oceanographer Iain Suthers from the University of New South Wales explained that the algae gives off a luminous glow as a defense mechanism against other algae called diatoms. A similar display was observed in Sydney's Manly Beach in August 2014, and experts assure that there is no need to be concerned about the algae.

New genetic tests called endopredict can determine the aggressiveness of breast cancer tumors and accurately assess the risk of recurrence, potentially sparing some patients from chemotherapy. The tests, which cost around £2,500, are currently available privately and may soon be offered on the NHS. Surgeons and breast cancer experts believe that the test can help patients make informed decisions about their treatment, as it can identify low-risk cases where chemotherapy may not be necessary. For example, a patient named Becca, who had breast cancer in both breasts, opted against chemotherapy after receiving a low score from the endopredict test, which indicated a five percent chance of recurrence within ten years.

The passage reports that over 25 women have been airlifted from Royal Navy ships due to pregnancy over the past nine years, with at least one instance involving HMS Illustrious, nicknamed "HMS Lusty." HMS Ocean had five pregnant sailors removed in emergency medevacs during this period. The Ministry of Defence confirmed a strict "no touching" rule at sea, suggesting women may have conceived before boarding or during leave. The data comes after Commander Sarah West, the first woman to captain a Royal Navy warship, was flown back to the UK following allegations of a sexual relationship with a crew member. The passage also mentions that women have served on Royal Navy ships since 1990, with 9% of personnel being female in 2014. Three women became the first female submariners in 2014, and nearly 100 women were evacuated from Afghanistan due to pregnancy between 2011 and 2013. Strict military rules ban mothers-to-be from serving in war zones, and most babies were conceived before deployment, though some may have become pregnant during service.

A drone carrying traces of radioactive cesium was discovered on the roof of Japan's prime minister's residence, raising concerns about potential terrorism, especially in light of upcoming events like the Olympics and G7 summit. The discovery comes amid Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's push to restart two nuclear reactors, which is unpopular due to safety concerns. The amount of cesium found is not immediately harmful, but the incident has prompted the government to review drone operation regulations and enhance counter-terrorism measures.

A Chinese security guard, Lu Xincai, takes his 84-year-old Alzheimer's suffering mother with him to work every day on the back of his motorbike in Zhejiang province, China. He does this to ensure she is not left alone, as she often got lost when left unsupervised in the past.
